editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations.>/p> Bohan Oberon Slipper Nano, a dwarf King of Scots Ateukin Sir Bartram Douglas Morton Ross Sir Cuthbert Anderson Bishop of St Andrews Andrew Snoord Purveyor Scout Jaques King of England Eustace Percy Samles Herald of the English army Tailor Shoemaker Multiple speakers Cutler Lawyer Merchant Divine Dorothea, Q of Scots Countess of Arran Lady Anderson Ida, daughter of Countess of Arran 1 Huntsman 2 Huntsman Servant inscription on tomb

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

body.stage: Enter After Oberon, King of Fairies, an Antique, who dance aboue a Tombe, placed conveniently on the Stage, out of the which, suddainly starts vp as they daunce, Bohan a Scot, attired like a ridstall man, from whom the Antique flies.

sp.speaker: Bohan.
sp.p: I say, what is thou?

sp.speaker: Oberon.
sp.p: Thy friend Bohan.

sp.speaker: Bohan.
sp.p: What wot I, or reck I that, why good man, I reck no friend, nor I reck no foe, all is even to me, git the ganging, and trouble not may whayet, or ays gar the reckon me nene of thy friend, by the marry mass, shall I.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: Why angry Scot, I visit thee for love: then what moves thee to wrath?

sp.speaker: Bohan.
sp.p: The deal a whit reck I thy love. For I know too well, that true love took her flight twenty winter sense to heaven, whither till I can, well I wot, I shall never find love: if thou lovest me, leave me to myself. But what were those Puppets that hopped and skipped about me year while?

sp.speaker: Oberon.
sp.p: My subjects.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p: Thy subjects, why art thou a King?

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: I am.

sp.speaker: Bohan.
sp.p: The deal thou art, why thou lookest not so big as the king of Clubs, nor so sharp as the king of Spades, nor so fain as the king of Diamonds, be the mass I take thee to be the king of false hearts: therefore I rid thee away, or I shall so curry your Kingdom, that you should be glad to run to save your life.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: Why stoycall Scot, do what thou darest to me, here is my breast strike.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p:
Thou wilt not threap me, this whinyard has guard many better men to lope than thou: but how now? Gos saidst what wilt
not out? why thou witch, thou deal, gads foot my whinyard.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: Why pull man: but what if it were out, how then?

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p:
This then, thou wert best begone first: for I will so lop
thy limbs, that thou shall go with half a knaves carcass to the deal

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: Draw it out, now strike fool, canst thou not?

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p: Bread aye gad, what deal is in me, why tell me thou skip-jack what art thou?

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: Nay first tell me what thou wast from thy birth, what thou hast past hitherto, why thou dwellest in a Tomb, and leavest the world? and then I will release thee of these bonds, before not.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p: And not before, then needs must needs shall: I was born a gentleman of the best blood in all Scotland, except the king, when time brought me to age, and death took my parents, I became a Courtier, where though I list not praise myself, I engraved the memory of Boughon on the skin-coat of some of them, and reveled with the proudest.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: But why living in such reputation, didst thou leave to be a Courtier?

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p: Because my pride was vanity, my expense loss, my reward fair words and large promises, and my hopes spilt, for that after many years service, one outran me, and what the deal should I then do there. No no, flattering knaves that can cog and prate fastest, speed best in the Court.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: To what life didst thou then betake thee?

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p:
I then changed the Court for the country, and the wars for a wife: but I found the craft of swains more vile, than the
knavery of courtiers: the charge of children more heavy than servants, and wives tongues worse than the wars itself: and therefore I gave over that, and went to the City to dwell, and there
I kept a great house with small cheer, but all was never the near.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: And why?

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p: because in seeking friends, I found table guests to eat me, and my meat, my wives gossips to bewray the secrets of my heart, kindred to betray the effect of my life, which when I noted, the court ill, the country worse, and the city worst of all, in good time my wife died: I would she had died twenty winter sooner by the mass, leaving my two sons to the world, and shutting myself into this Tomb, where if I die, I am sure I am safe from wild beasts, but whilst I live, cannot be free from ill company. Besides, now I am sure if all my friends fail me, I shall have a grave of mine own providing: this is all. Now what art thou?

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: Oberon King of Fairies, that loves thee because thou hatest the world, and to gratulate thee, I brought those Antics to show thee some sport in dancing, which thou hast loved well.

sp.speaker: Bohan.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, thinkest thou those puppets can please me? why I have two sons, that with one scottish jig shall break the neck of thy Antics.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: That would I fain see.

sp.speaker: Boha.
sp.p: Why thou shalt, how boys.
Hold your clacks lads, trattle not for thy life, but gather up your legs and dance me forthwith a jig worth the sight.

sp.speaker: Slip..
sp.p: Why I must talk if I die for it, wherefore was my tongue made.

sp.speaker: Boha.
sp.p:
Prattle if thou darest e'en word more, and I shall dab this
whinyard in thy womb.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: Be quiet Bohan, I will strike him dumb, and his brother too, their talk shall not hinder our jig, fall to it, dance I say man.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p: Dance Humer, dance, I rid thee.
sp.stage: The two dance a gig devised for the nonst.
sp.p:
Now get you to the wide world with more than my father gave
me, that is learning enough, both kinds, knavery and honesty: and that I gave you, spend at pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p:
Nay for their sport I will give them this gift, to the
Dwarf I give a quick wit, pretty of body, and a warrant his preferment to a Princes service, where by his wisdom he shall gain more love than common. And to loggerhead your son, I give a wandering life, and promise he shall never lack: and avow that if in all distresses he call upon me to help him: now let them go.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.p:
Now King, if thou be a King, I will show thee why I hate the world by demonstration, in the year 1520. was in Scotland, a king overruled with parasites, misled by lust, and many circumstances, too long to trattle on now, much like our court of Scotland this day, that story have I set down, gang with
me to the gallery, and I will show thee the same in Action, by good fellows of our country men, and then when thou seest that, judge if any wise man would not leave the world if he could.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.p: That will I see, lead and I will follow thee.

div1.head: Actus primus. Scena prima.
div1.stage: Enter the King of England, the King of Scots, Dorithe his Queen, the Countess, Lady Ida, with other Lords. And Ateukin with them aloofe.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: Brother of England, since our neighbouring land,
And near alliance doth invite our loves,
The more I think upon our last accord,
The more I grieve your sudden parting hence:
First laws of friendship did confirm our peace,
Now both the seal of faith and marriage bed,
The name of father, and the style of friend,
These force in me affection full confirmed,
So that I grieve, and this my hearty grief
The heavens record, the world may witness well
To lose your presence, who are now to me
A father, brother, and a vowed friend.

sp.speaker: K. of Eng.
sp.l: Link all these lovely stiles good king in one,
And since thy grief exceeds in my depart,
I leave my Dorubea to enjoy, thy whole compact
Loves, and plighted vows.
Brother of Scotland, this is my joy, my life,
Her fathers honour, and her Countries hope,
Her mothers comfort, and her husbands bliss:
I tell thee king, in loving of my Doll,
Thou bindest her fathers heart and all his friends
In bands of love that death cannot dissolve.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: Nor can her father love her like to me,
My lives light, and the comfort of my soul:
Fair Dorithea, that wast Englands pride,
Welcome to Scotland, and in sign of love,
Lo I invest thee with the Scottish Crown.
Nobles and Ladies, stoop unto your Queen.
And Trumpets sound, that Heralds may proclaim,
Fair Dorrhea peerless Queen of Scots.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long live and prosper our fair Queen of Scots.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thanks to the king of kings for my dignity,
Thanks to my father, that provides so carefully,
Thanks to my Lord and husband for this honour,
And thanks to all that love their King and me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Long live fair Dorithea our true Queen.

sp.speaker: K. of E.
sp.l: Long shine the sun of Scotland in her pride,
Her fathers comfort, and fair Scotland's Bride.
But Dorithea, since I must depart,
And leave thee from thy tender mothers charge,
Let me advise my lovely daughter first,
What best befits her in a foreign land,
Live Doll, for many eyes shall look on thee,
Have care of honour and the present state:
For she that steps to height of Majesty,
Is even the mark whereat the enemy aims.
Thy virtues shall be construed to vice,
Thine affable discourse to abject mind.
If coy, detracting tongues will call thee proud:
Be therefore wary in this slippery state,
Honour thy husband, love him as thy life:
Make choice of friends, as Eagles of their young,
Who sooth no vice, who flatter not for gain:
But love such friends as do the truth maintain.
Think on these lessons when thou art alone,
And thou shalt live in health when I am gone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I will engrave these preceps in my heart,
And as the wind with calmness woes you hence,
Even so I wish the heavens in all mishaps,
May bless my father with continual grace.

sp.speaker: K. of E.
sp.l: Then son farewell, the favouring winds invites us to depart.
Long circumstance in taking princely leaves,
Is more officious than convenient.
Brother of Scotland, love me in my child,
You greet me well, if so you will her good.

sp.speaker: K. of Sc.
sp.l: Then lovely Doll, and all that favour me,
Attend to see our English friends at sea,
Let all their charge depend upon my purse:
They are our neighbours, by whose kind accord,
We dare attempt the proudest Potentate.
Only fair Countess, and your daughter stay,
With you I have some other thing to say.

div1.stage: Exeunt all saue the King, the Countess, Ida, Ateukin, in all royaltie.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: So let them triumph that have cause to joy,
But wretched King, thy nuptial knot is death:
Thy Bride the breeder of thy Countries ill,
For thy false heart dissenting from thy hand,
Misled by love, hast made another choice,
Another choice, even when thou vowedest thy soul
To Dorithea, Englands choicest pride,
O then thy wandering eyes bewitched thy heart,
Even in the Chapel did thy fancy change,
When perjured man, though fair Doll had thy hand,
The Scottish Idaes beauty stale thy heart:
Yet fear and love hath tide thy ready tongue
From blabbing forth the passions of thy mind,
Lest fearful silence have in subtle looks
Bewrayed the treason of my new vowed love,
Be fair and lovely Doll, but here is the prize
That lodgeth here, and entered through mine eyes,
Yet howsoever I love, I must be wise.
Now lovely Countess, what reward or grace,
May I employ on you for this your zeal,
And humble honours done us in our Court,
In entertainment of the English King.

sp.speaker: Countess.
sp.l: It was of duty Prince that I have done:
And what in favour may content me most,
Is, that it please your grace to give me leave,
For to return unto my Country home.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: But lovely Ida is your mind the same?

sp.speaker: Ida.
sp.l: I count of Court my Lord, as wise men do,
It is fit for those that knows what longs thereto:
Each person to his place, the wise to Art,
The Cobbler to his clout, the Swain to Cart.

sp.speaker: K. of Sc.
sp.l: But Ida you are fair, and beauty shines,
And seemeth best, where pomp her pride refines.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: If beauty (as I know there is none in me)
Were sworn my love, and I his life should be:
The farther from the Court I were removed,
The more I think of heaven I were beloved.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Because the Court is counted Venus net,
Where gifts and vows for stales are often set,
None, be she chaste as Vesta, but shall meet
A curious tongue to charm her ears with sweet.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: Why Ida then I see you set at naught,
The force of love.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: In sooth this is my thought most gracious king,
That they that little prove
Are mickle blessed, from bitter sweets of love:
And well I wot, I heard a shepherd sing,
That like a Bee, Love hath a little sting:
He lurks in flowers, he percheth on the trees,
He on Kings pillows, bends his pretty knees:
The Boy is blind, but when he will not spy,
He hath a leaden foot, and wings to fly:
Beshrew me yet, for all these strange effects,
If I would like the Lad, that so infects.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: Rare wit, fair face, what heart could more desire!
But Doll is fair, and doth concern thee near.
Let Doll be fair, she is won, but I must woe,
And win fair Ida, there is some choice in two.
But Ida thou art coy.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: And why dread King?

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: In that you will dispraise so sweet
A thing, as love, had I my wish.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: What then?

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: Then would I place his arrow here,
His beauty in that face.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: And were Apollo moved and ruled by me,
His wisdom should be yours, and mine his tree.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: But here returns our train.
Welcome fair Doll how fares our father, is he shipped and gone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: My royal father is both shipped and gone,
God and fair winds direct him to his home.

sp.speaker: K. of Sc.
sp.l: Amen say I, would thou wert with him too:
Then might I have a fitter time to woo.
But Countess you would be gone, therefore farewell
Yet Ida if thou wilt, stay thou behind,
To accompany my Queen.
But if thou like the pleasures of the Court,
Or if she liked me though she left the Court,
What should I say? I know not what to say,
You may depart, and you my courteous Queen.
Leave me a space, I have a weighty cause to think upon.
Ida, it nips me near:
It came from thence, I feel it burning here.

div1.stage: Exeunt all saving the King and Ateukin.

sp.speaker: K. of Scot.
sp.l: Now am I free from sight of common eye,
Where to myself I may disclose the grief
That hath too great a part in mine affects.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: And now is my time, by wiles and words to rise,
Greater than those, that thinks themselves more wise.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: And first fond King, thy honour doth engrave,
Upon thy brows, the drift of thy disgrace:
Thy new vowed love in sight of God and men,
Link thee to Dorithea, during life.
For who more fair and virtuous than thy wife,
Deceitful murtherer of a quiet mind,
Fond love, vile lust, that thus misleads us men,
To vow our faiths, and fall to sin again.
But Kings stoop not to every common thought,
Ida is fair and wise, fit for a King:
And for fair Ida will I hazard life,
Venture my Kingdom, Country, and my Crown:
Such fire hath love, to burn a kingdom down.
Say Doll dislikes, that I estrange my love,
Am I obedient to a woman's look?
Nay say her father frown when he shall hear
That I do hold fair Idaes love so dear:
Let father frown and fret, and fret and die,
Nor earth, nor heaven shall part my love and I.
Yea they shall part us, but we first must meet,
And woo, and win, and yet the world not see it.
Yea there is the wound, and wounded with that thought
So let me die: for all my drift is naught.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Most gracious and imperial Majesty,

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: A little flattery more were but too much,
Villain what art thou that thus darest interrupt a Princes secrets.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Dread King, thy vassal is a man of Art,
Who knows by constellation of the stars,
By oppositions and by dry aspects,
The things are past, and those that are to come.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: But where is thy warrant to approach my presence?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: My zeal and ruth to see your graces wrong,
Makes me lament, I did detract so long.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: If thou knowest thoughts, tell me what mean I now?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: I will calculate the cause of those your highness smiles,
And tell your thoughts.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: But lest thou spend thy time in idleness,
And miss the matter that my mind aims at,
Tell me what star was opposite when that was thought?

div1.stage: He strikes him on the eare.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: It is inconvenient mighty Potentate,
Whose looks resembles Jove in Majesty,
To scorn the sooth of science with contempt,
I see in those imperial looks of yours,
The whole discourse of love, Saturn combust,
With direful looks at your nativity:
Beheld fair Venus in her silver orb,
I know by certain axioms I have read,
Your graces griefs, and further can express her name,
That holds you thus in fancies bands.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Thou talkest wonders.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Naught but truth O King,
It is Ida is the mistress of your heart,
Whose youth must take impression of affects,
For tender twigs will bow, and milder minds
Will yield to fancy be they followed well.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: What god art thou composed in human shape,
Or bold Trophonius to decide our doubts,
How knowest thou this?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Even as I know the means,
To work your graces freedom and your love:
Had I the mind as many Courtiers have,
To creep into your bosom for your coin,
And beg rewards for every cap and knee,
I then would say, if that your grace would give
This lease, this manor, or this patent sealed,
For this or that I would effect your love:
But Ateukin is no Parasite O Prince,
I know your grace knows scholars are but poor,
And therefore as I blush to beg a fee,
Your mightiness is so magnificent
You cannot choose but cast some gift apart,
To ease my bashful need that cannot beg,
As for your love, O might I be employed,
How faithfully would Ateukin compass it:
But Princes rather trust a smoothing tongue,
Than men of Art that can accept the time.

sp.speaker: K. of Scots.
sp.l: Ateu. If so thy name, for so thou sayst,
Thine Art appears in entrance of my love:
And since I deem thy wisdom matched with truth,
I will exalt thee, and thyself alone
Shalt be the Agent to dissolve my grief.
Sooth is, I love, and Ida is my love,
But my new marriage nips me near, Ateukin:
For Dorithea may not brooke the abuse.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: These lets are but as moths against the sun,
Yet not so great, like dust before the wind:
Yet not so light. Tut pacify your grace,
You have the sword and sceptre in your hand,
You are the King, the state depends on you:
Your will is law, say that the case were mine,
Were she my sister whom your highness loves,
She should consent, for that our lives, our goods,
Depend on you, and if your Queen repine,
Although my nature cannot brooke of blood,
And Scholars grieve to hear of murtherous deeds,
But if the Lamb should let the lions way,
By my advise the Lamb should lose her life.
Thus am I bold to speak unto your grace,
Who am too base to kiss your royal feet,
For I am poor, nor have I land nor rent,
Nor countenance here in Court, but for my love,
Your Grace shall find none such within the realm.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Wilt thou effect my love, shall she be mine?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: I will gather Moly-rocus, and the herbs,
That heels the wounds of body and the mind,
I will set out charms and spells, naught else shall be left,
To tame the wanton if she shall rebel,
Give me but tokens of your highness trust.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Thou shalt have gold, honour and wealth enough,
Win my Love, and I will make thee great.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: These words do make me rich most noble Prince,
I am more proud of them than any wealth,
Did not your grace suppose I flatter you,
Believe me I would boldly publish this:
Was never eye that saw a sweeter face,
Nor never ear that heard a deeper wit,
O God how I am ravished in your worth.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Ateu. Follow me, love must have ease.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: I will kiss your highness feet, march when you please.

div1.stage: Enter Slipper, Nano, and Andrew, with their billes ready written in their hands.

sp.speaker: Andrew.
sp.l: Stand back sir, mine shall stand highest.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Come under mine arm sir, or get a footstool,
Or else by the light of the Moon, I must come to it.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Agree my masters, every man to his height,
Though I stand lowest, I hope to get the best master.

sp.speaker: Anar.
sp.l: Ere I will stoop to a thistle, I will change turns,
As good luck comes on the right hand, as the left:
Here is for me, and me, and mine.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: But tell me fellows till better occasion come,
Do you seek masters?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: We do.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: But what can you do worthy preferment?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Marry I can smell a knave from a Rat.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: And I can lick a dish before a Cat.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: And I can find two fools unsought,
How like you that?
But in earnest, now tell me of what trades are you two?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: How mean you that sir, of what trade?
Marry I will tell you, I have many trades,
The honest trade when I needs must,
The filching trade when time serves,
The Cozening trade as I find occasion.
And I have more qualities, I cannot abide a full cup unkissed,
A fat Capon uncarved,
A full purse unpicked,
Nor a fool to prove a Justice as you do.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Why sot why callest thou me fool?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: For examining wiser than thyself.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: So doth many more than I in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Yea those are such, as have more authority than wit,
And more wealth than honesty.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: This is my little brother with the great wit, ware him,
But what canst thou do, tell me, that art so inquisitive of us?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Anything that concerns a gentleman to do, that can I do.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: So you are of the gentle trade?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Then gentle sir, leave us to ourselves,
For here comes one as if he would lack a servant ere he went.
Why so Ateukin? this becomes thee best,
Wealth, honour, ease, and angels in thy chest:
Now may I say, as many often sing,
No fishing to the sea, nor service to a king.
Unto this high promotions doth belong,
Means to be talked of in the thickest throng:
And first to fit the humours of my Lord,
Sweet lays and lines of love I must record.
And such sweet lines and love-lays I will indict:
As men may wish for, and my leech delight,
And next a train of gallants at my heels,
That men may say, the world doth run on wheels.
For men of art, that rise by indirection,
To honour and the favour of their King,
Must use all means to save what they have got,
And win their favours whom he never knew.
If any frown to see my fortunes such,
A man must bear a little, not too much:
But in good time these bills portend, I think,
That some good fellows do for service seek.

sp.p:
If any gentleman, spiritual or temporal, will entertain out of his service, a young stripling of the age of thirty years, that can sleep with the soundest, eat with the hungriest, work with the sickest, lie with the loudest, face with the proudest, that can wait in a Gentleman's chamber, when his master is a mile off, keep his stable
when it is empty, and his purse when it is full, and hath many qualities worse than all these, let him write his name and go his way, and attendance shall be given.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: By my faith a good servant, which is he?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Truly sir that am I?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: And why dost thou write such a bill,
Are all these qualities in thee?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: O Lord aye sir, and a great many more,
Some better, some worse, some richer some poorer,
Why sir do you look so, do they not please you?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Truly no, for they are naught and so art thou,
If thou hast no better qualities, stand by.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: O sir, I tell the worst first, but if you lack a man.
I am for you, I will tell you the best qualities I have.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Be brief then.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: If you need me in your chamber,
I can keep the door at a whistle, in your kitchen,
Turn the spit, and lick the pan, and make the fire burn.
But if in the stable.

sp.speaker: Steu.
sp.l: Yea there would I use thee.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Why there you kill me, there am I,
And turn me to a horse and a wench, and I have no peer.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Art thou so good in keeping a horse,
I pray thee tell me how many good qualities hath a horse?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Why so sir, a horse hath two properties of a man,
That is a proud heart, and a hardy stomach,
Four properties of a lion, a broad breast, a stiff docket,
Hold your nose master. A wild countenance, and four good legs.
Nine properties of a Fox, nine of a Hare, nine of an Ass,
And ten of a woman.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: A woman, why what properties of a woman hath a Horse?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: O master, know you not that?
Draw your tables, and write what wise I speak.
First a merry countenance.
Second, a soft pace.
Third, a broad forehead.
Fourth, broad buttocks.
Fifth, hard of ward.
Sixth, easy to leap upon.
Seventh, good at long journey.
Eight, moving under a man.
Ninth, always busy with the mouth.
Tenth. Ever chewing on the bridle.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Thou art a man for me, what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: An ancient name sir, belonging to the
Chamber and the night gown. Guess you that.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: What is that, Slipper?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: By my faith well guessed, and so it is indeed:
You will be my master?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: I mean so.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Read this first.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Pleaseth it any Gentleman to entertain
A servant of more wit than stature,
Let them subscribe, and attendance shall be given.
What of this?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: He is my brother sir, and we two were born together,
Must serve together, and will die together,
Though we be both hanged.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Nano.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: The etymology of which word, is a dwarf:
Art not thou the old stoykes son that dwells in his Tomb?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: We are.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Thou art welcome to me,
Wilt thou give thyself wholly to be at my disposition?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: In all humility I submit myself.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Then will I deck thee Princely, instruct thee courtly,
And present thee to the Queen as my gift.
Art thou content?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Yes, and thank your honour too.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Then welcome brother, and fellow now.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: May it please your honour to abase your eye so low,
As to look either on my bill or myself.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: By birth a gentleman, in profession a scholar,
And one that knew your honour in Edenborough,
Before your worthiness called you to this reputation.
By me Andrew Snoord.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Andrew I remember thee, follow me,
And we will confer further, for my weighty affairs
For the king, commands me to be brief at this time.
Come on Nano, Slipper follow.

div1.stage: Enter sir Bartram with Eustas and others, booted.

sp.speaker: S. Bar.
sp.l: But tell me lovely Eustas as thou lovest me,
Among the many pleasures we have past,
Which is the rifest in thy memory,
To draw thee over to thine ancient friend?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: What makes Sir Bartram thus inquisitive?
Tell me good knight, am I welcome or no?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.l: By sweet Saint Andrew and my sale I swear,
As welcome is my honest Dick to me,
As mornings sun, or as the watery moon,
In murkiest night, when we the borders track.
I tell thee Dick, thy sight hath cleared my thoughts,
Of many baneful troubles that there wound.
Welcome to sir Bartram as his life:
Tell me bonny Dicke, hast got a wife?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: A wife God shield sir Bartram, that were ill
To leave my wife and wander thus astray:
But time and good advise ere many years,
May chance to make my fancy bend that way,
What news in Scotland? therefore came I hither:
To see your Country, and to chat together.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.l: Why man our Country is blithe, our king is well,
Our Queen so, so, the Nobles well, and worse
And well are they that were about the king,
But better are the Country Gentlemen.
And I may tell thee Eustace, in our lives,
We old men never saw so wondrous change:
But leave this trattle, and tell me what news,
In lovely England with our honest friends?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: The king, the Court, and all our noble friends
Are well, and God in mercy keep them so.
The Northern Lords and Ladies hereabouts,
That knows I came to see your Queen and Court,
Commends them to my honest friend sir Bartram,
And many others that I have not seen:
Among the rest, the Countess Elinor from Carlile
Where we merry oft have been,
Greets well my Lord, and hath directed me,
By message this fair Ladies face to see.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.l: I tell thee Eustace, lest mine old eyes daze,
This is our Scottish moon and evenings pride:
This is the blemish of your English Bride:
Who sails by her, are sure of wind at will.
Her face is dangerous, her sight is ill:
And yet in sooth sweet Dicke, it may be said,
The king hath folly, there is virtue in the maid.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: But knows my friend this portrait, be advised?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.l: Is it not Ida the Countess of Arains daughters?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: So was I told by Elinor of Carlile,
But tell me lovely Bartram, is the maid evil inclined,
Misled, or Concubine unto the King or any other Lord?

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Should I be brief and true, then thus my Dicke,
All Englands grounds yields not a blither Lass.
Nor Europ can art her for her gifts,
Of virtue, honour, beauty, and the rest:
But our fond king not knowing sin in lust,
Makes love by endless means and precious gifts,
And men that see it dare not say it my friend,
But we may wish that it were otherwise:
But I rid thee to view the picture still,
For by the persons sights there hangs some ill.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: O good sir Bartram, you suspect I love,
Then were I mad, he whom I never saw,
But howsoever, I fear not enticings,
Desire will give no place unto a king:
I will see her whom the world admires so much,
That I may say with them, there lives none such.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Be Gad and shall, both see and talk with her,
And when thou hast done, whatever her beauty be,
I will warrant thee her virtues may compare,
With the proudest she that waits upon your Queen.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: My Lady entreats your Worship in to supper.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.l: Good bony Dick, my wife will tell thee more,
Was never no man in her book before:
Be Gad she is blithe, fair lewely, bony,

div1.stage: Enter Bohan and the fairy king after the first act, to them a round of Fairies, or some pretty dance.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: Be Gad gramercy little king for this,
This sport is better in my exile life,
Than ever the deceitful world could yield.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: I tell thee Bohan, Oberon is king,
Of quiet, pleasure, profit, and content,
Of wealth, of honour, and of all the world,
Tide to no place, yet all are tide to one,
Live thou in this life, exiled from world and men,
And I will show thee wonters ere we part,

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: Then mark my stay, and the strange doubts,
That follow flatterers, lust and lawless will,
And then say I have reason to forsake the world,
And all that are within the same.
Go shroud us in our harbour where we will see,
The pride of folly, as it ought to be.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: Here see I good fond actions in thy jig,
And means to paint the worlds in constant ways
But turn thine e'en, see which for I can command.

div1.stage: Enter two battles strongly fighting, the one Simi Ranus, the other, Staurobates, she flies, and her Crown is taken, and she hurt.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: What gars this din of murk and baleful harm,
Where every wean is all betaint with blood?

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: This shows thee Bohan what is worldly pomp.
Simeranus, the proud Assirrian Queen,
When Ninus died, did ten in her wars,
Three millions of footmen to the fight,
Five hundredth thousand horse, of armed chars,
A hundredth thousand more yet in her pride
Was hurt and conquered by Saint Taurobates.
Then what is pomp?

sp.speaker: Bohan.
sp.l: I see thou art thine e'en,
Thou bonny King, if Princes fail from high,
My fall is past, until I fall to die.
Now mark my talk, and prosecute my jig.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: How should these crafts withdraw thee from the world?
But look my Bohan, pomp allureth.

div1.stage: Enter Cirus king, humbling themselues: himselfe crowned by Oliue Pat that, at last dying, layde in a marble tombe with this inscription

sp.p: Whoso thou be that passest, For I know one shall pass, know I I am Cirus of Persia, And I prithee leave me not thus like a clod of clay Wherewith my body is covered.

div1.stage: Enter the king in great pompe, who reads it, & issueth, crieth vermeum.

sp.speaker: Boha.
sp.l: What meaneth this?

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: Cirus of Persia,
Mighty in life, within a marble grave,
Was laid to rot, whom Alexander once
Beheld intombed, and weeping did confess
Nothing in life could scape from wretchedness:
Why then boast men?

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: What reck I then of life,
Who makes the grave my tomb, the earth my wife:
But mark me more.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: I can no more, my patience will not warp.
To see these flatteries how they scorn and carp.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: Turn but thy head.

div1.stage: Enter our kings carring Crowns, Ladies presenting odors to Potentates inthroned, who suddainly is slaine by his servant, and thrust out, and so they eate.

sp.l: Sick is the world, but who is he I saw.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: Sesestiis who was conqueror of the world,
Slain at the last, and stamped on by his slaves.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: How blessed are pure men then that know their grave,
Now mark the sequel of my Cig.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: An he well meet ends: the murk and sable night
Doth leave the peering morn to pry abroad,
Thou nil me stay, hail then thou pride of kings,
I ken the world, and wot well worldly things,
Mark thou my jig, in murkiest terms that tells
The loathe of sins, and where corruption dwells
Hail me ne more with shows of godly sights:
My grave is mine, that rids me from despites.
Accept my gig good King, and let me rest,
The grave with good men, is a gay built nest.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: The rising sun doth call me hence away,
Thanks for thy jig, I may no longer stay:
But if my train, did wake thee from thy rest,
So shall they sing, thy lullaby to nest.

div1.head: Actus Secundus. Schena Prima.
div1.stage: Enter the Countess of Arrain, with Ida her daughter in theyr porch, sitting at worke. A song.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Fair Ida, might you choose the greatest good
Midst all the world, in blessings that abound:
Wherein my daughter should your liking be?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Not in delights, or pomp, or majesty.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Since these are means to draw the mind
From perfect good, and make true judgment blind.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Might you have wealth, and fortunes richest store?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Yet would I (might I choose) be honest poor.
For she that sits at fortunes feet allow
Is sure she shall not taste a further woe.
But those that prank on top of fortunes ball,
Still fear a change: and fearing catch a fall.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Tut foolish maid, each one contemneth need.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Good reason why, they know not good indeed.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Many marry then, on whom distress doth lower,

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Yes they that virtue deem an honest dower.
Madam, by right this world I may compare,
Unto my work, wherein with heedful care,
The heavenly workman plants with curious hand,
As I with needle draw each thing on land,
Even as he list, some men like to the Rose,
Are fashioned fresh, some in their stalks do close,
And born do sudden die: some are but weeds,
And yet from them a secret good proceeds:
I with my needle if I please may blot,
The fairest rose within my cambric plot,
God with a beck can change each worldly thing,
The poor to earth, the beggar to the king.
What then hath man, wherein he well may boast,
Since by a beck he lives, a lover is lost?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Peace Ida, here are strangers neare at hand.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Madam God speed.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I thank you gentle squire.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: The country Countess of Northumberland,
Doth greet you well, and hath requested me,
To bring these letters to your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I thank her honour, and yourself my friend
I see she means you good brave Gentleman,
Daughter, the Lady Elinor salutes
Yourself as well as me, then for her sake
It were good you entertained that Courtier well.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: As much salute as may become my sex,
And he in virtue can vouchsafe to think,
I yield him for the courteous Countess sake.
Good sir sit down, my mother here and I,
Count time misspent, an endless vanity.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Beyond report, the wit, the fair, the shape,
What work you here, fair Mistress may I see it?

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: Good Sir look on, how like you this compact?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Methinks in this I see true love in act:
The Woodbines with their leaves do sweetly spread,
The Roses blushing prank them in their red,
No flower but boasts the beauties of the spring,
This bird hath life indeed if it could sing:
What means fair Mistress had you in this work?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: My needle sir.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: In needles then there lurks,
Some hidden grace I deem beyond my reach.

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: Not grace in them good sir, but those that teach.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Say that your needle now were Cupids sting,
But ah her eye must be no less,
In which is heaven and heavenliness,
In which the food of God is shut,
Whose powers the purest minds do glut.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: What if it were?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Then see a wondrous thing,
I fear me you would paint in Teneus heart,
Affection in his power and chiefest parts.

sp.speaker: Ida.
sp.l: Good Lord sir no, for hearts but pricked soft,
Are wounded sore, for so I hear it oft.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: what racks the second,
Where but your happy eye,
May make him live, whom Jove hath judged to die.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Should life and death within this needle lurk,
I will prick no hearts, I will prick upon my work.

div1.stage: Enter Ateuken, with Slipper the Clown.

sp.speaker: Coun.
sp.l: Peace Ida, I perceive the fox at hand.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: The fox? why fetch your hounds and chase him hence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: O sir these great men bark at small offence.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Come will it please you to enter gentle sir?
Stay courteous Ladies, favour me so much,
As to discourse a word or two apart.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Good sir, my daughter learns this rule of me,
To shun resort, and strangers company:
For some are shifting mates that carry letters,
Some such as you too good, because our betters.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Now I pray you sir what a kin are you to a pickerel?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Why knave?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
By my troth sir, because I never knew a proper situation
fellow of your pitch, fitter to swallow a gudgeon.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: What meanest thou by this?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Shifting fellow sir, these be thy words, shifting fellow:
This Gentlewoman I fear me, knew your bringing up.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: How so?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why sir your father was a Miller, That could shift for a peck of grist in a bushel, And you a fair spoken Gentleman, that can get more land by a lie, than an honest man by his ready money.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Caitiff what sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I say sir, that if she call you shifting knave, You shall not put her to the proof.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: And why?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Because sir, living by your wit as you do shifting, is your letters patents, it were a hard matter for me to get my
dinner that day, wherein my Master had not sold a dozen of devices, a case of cogs, and a chute of shifts in the morning: I speak this in your commendation sir, and I pray you so take it.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.p: If I live knave I will be revenged, what Gentleman would entertain a rascal, thus to derogate from his honour?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: My Lord why are you thus impatient?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Not angry Ida, but I teach this knave,
How to behave himself among his betters:
Behold fair Countess to assure your stay,
I here present the signet of the king,
Who now by me fair Ida doth salute you:
And since in secret I have certain things,
In his behalf good Madam to impart,
I crave your daughter to discourse apart.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: She shall in humble duty be addressed,
To do his Highness will in what she may.

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: Now gentle sir what would his grace with me?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Fair comely Nymph, the beauty of your face,
Sufficient to bewitch the heavenly powers,
Hath wrought so much in him, that now of late
He finds himself made captive unto love,
And though his power and Majesty requires,
A straight command before an humble suit,
Yet he his mightiness doth so abase,
As to entreat your favour honest maid.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Is he not married sir unto our Queen?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: He is.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: And are not they by God accursed,
That sever them whom he hath knit in one?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: They be: what then? we seek not to displace
The Princess from her seat, but since by love
The king is made your own, she is resolved
In private to accept your dalliance,
In spite of war, watch, or worldly eye.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: O how he talks as if he should not die,
As if that God in justice once could wink,
Upon that fault I am a shamed to think.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Tut Mistress, man at first was born to err,
Women are all not formed to be Saints:
It is impious for to kill our native king,
Whom by a little favour we may save.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Better than live unchaste, to live in grave.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: He shall erect your state and wed you well.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: But can his warrant keep my soul from hell?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: He will enforce, if you resist his suit.

sp.speaker: Id.
sp.l: What though, the world may shame to him account
To be a king of men and worldly pelf.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Yet hath to power no rule and guide himself,
I know you gentle Lady and the care,
Both of your honour and his graces health,
Makes me confused in this dangerous state.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: So counsel him, but sooth thou not his sin,
It is vain allurement that doth make him love,
I shame to hear, be you ashamed to move.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: I see my daughter grows impatient,
I fear me he pretends some bad intent.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Will you despise the king, and scorn him so?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: In all allegiance I will serve his grace,
But not in lust, O how I blush to name it?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: An endless work is this, how should I frame it?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: O Mistress may I turn a word upon you.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Friend what wilt thou?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: O what a happy Gentlewoman be you truly, the world reports this of you Mistress, that a man can no sooner come to your house, but the Butler comes with a black Jack and says welcome friend, here is a cup of the best for you, verily Mistress you are said to have the best Ale in all Scotland.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Sirrah go fetch him drink, how likest thou this?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Like it Mistress? why this is quinsy quarry pepper de watchet, single goby, of all that ever I tasted: I will prove in
this Ale and tossed, the compass of the whole world. First this is the earth, it ties in the middle a fair browne tossed, a goodly country for hungry teeth to dwell upon: next this is the sea, a fair poole for a dry tongue to fish in: now come I, and seeing the world is naught, I divide it thus, and because the sea cannot stand without the earth, as Arist. saith, I put the both into their first Chaos which is my belly, and so mistress you may see your ale is become a miracle.

sp.speaker: Eustace.
sp.p: A merry mate Madam I promise you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why sigh you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Truly Madam, to think upon the world, which since I denounced, it keeps such a rumbling in my stomach, that unless your cook give it a counterbuff with some of your roasted Capons or beef, I fear me I shall become a loose body, so dainty I think, I shall neither hold fast before nor behind.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Go take him in and feast this merry swain,
Sirrah, my cook is your physician.
He hath a purge for to digest the world.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Will you not, Ida, grant his highness this?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: As I have said, in duty I am his:
For other lawless lusts, that ill beseem him,
I cannot like, and good I will not deem him.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Ida come in, and sir if so you please,
Come take a homely widows entertain.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: If he have no great haste, he may come nigh.
If haste, though he be gone, I will not cry.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: I see this labour lost, my hope in vain,
Yet will I try another drift again.

div1.stage: Enter the Bishop of S. Andrewes, Earle Douglas, Morton with others, one way, the Queene with Dwarfes an other way.

sp.speaker: B. S. Andr.
sp.l: O wrack of Common-weal! O wretched state!

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: O hapless flock whereas the guide is blind?

div1.stage: They all are in a muse.

sp.speaker: Mort.
sp.l: O heedless youth, where counsel is despised.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: Come pretty knave, and prank it by my side.
Let us see your best attendance out of hand.

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.l: Madam although my limbs are very small,
My heart is good, I will serve you therewithal.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: How if I were assailed, what couldst thou do?

sp.speaker: Dwarf.
sp.l: Madam call help, and boldly fight it too,
Although a Bee be but a little thing:
You know fair Queen, it hath a bitter sting.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How couldst thou do me good were I in grief?

sp.speaker: Dwar.
sp.l: Counsel dear Princes, is a choice relief.
Though Nestor wanted force, great was his wit,
And though I am but weak, my words are fit.

sp.speaker: S. And.
sp.l: Like to a ship upon the Ocean seas,
Tossed in the doubtful stream without a helm,
Such is a Monarch without good advice,
I am overheard, cast rain upon thy tongue,
Andrewes beware, reproof will breed a scar.

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: Good day my Lord.

sp.speaker: B. S. And.
sp.l: Lord Morton well met:
Whereon deems Lord Douglas all this while?

sp.speaker: Dou.
sp.l: Of that which yours and my poor heart doth break:
Although fear shuts our mouths we dare not speak.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What mean these Princes sadly to consult?
Somewhat I fear, betideth them amiss,
They are so pale in looks, so vexed in mind:
In happy hour the Noble Scottish Peers
Have I encountered you, what makes you mourn?

sp.speaker: B. S. And.
sp.l: If we with patience may attentive gain,
Your Grace shall know the cause of all our grief.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Speak on good father, come and sit by me:
I know thy care is for the common good.

sp.speaker: B. S. And.
sp.l: As fortune mighty Princes reareth some,
To high estate, and place in Common-weal,
So by divine bequest to them is lent,
A riper judgment and more searching eye:
Whereby they may discern the common harm,
For where importunes in the world are most,
Where all our profits rise and still increase,
There is our mind, thereon we meditate,
And what we do partake of good advice,
That we employ for to concern the same.)
To this intent these nobles and myself,
That are (or should be) eyes of Common-weal,
Seeing his highness reachless course of youth
His lawless and unbridled vain in love,
His too intentive trust too flatteries,
His abject care of council and his friends,
Cannot but grieve, and since we cannot draw
His eye or Judgment to discern his faults
Since we have spake and counsel is not heard,
I for my part, (let others as they list)
Will leave the Court, and leave him to his will:
Lest with a ruthful eye I should behold,
His overthrow which sore I fear is nigh.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Ah father are you so estranged from love,
From due allegiance to your Prince and land,
To leave your King when most he needs your help,
The thrifty husbandmen, are never wont
That see their lands unfruitful, to forsake them:
But when the mold is barren and unapt,
They toil, they plough, and make the fallow fat:
The pilot in the dangerous seas is known,
In calmer waves the silly sailor strives,
Are you not members Lords of Common-weal,
And can your head, your dear anointed King,
Default ye Lords, except yourselves do fail?
O stay your steps, return and counsel him.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: Men seek not moss upon a rolling stone,
Or water from the sieve, or fire from ice:
Or comfort from a reckless monarchs hands.
Madam he sets us light that served in Court,
In place of credit in his fathers days,
If we but enter presence of his grace,
Our payment is a frown, a scoff, a frump,
Whilst flattering Gnato pranks it by his side,
Soothing the careless King in his misdeeds,
And if your grace consider your estate,
His life should urge you too if all be true.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: Why Douglas why?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: As if you have not heard
His lawless love to Ida grown of late,
His careless estimate of your estate.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Ah Douglas thou misconsterest his intent,
He doth but tempt his wife, he tries my love:
This injury pertains to me, not to you.
The King is young, and if he step awry,
He may amend, and I will love him still.
Should we disdain our vines because they sprout
Before their time? or young men if they strain
Beyond their reach? no vines that bloom and spread
Do promise fruits, and young men that are wild,
In age grow wise, my friends and Scottish Peers,
If that an English Princess may prevail,
Stay, stay with him, lo how my zealous prayer
Is plead with tears, fie Peers will you hence?

sp.speaker: S. And.
sp.l: Madam it is virtue in your grace to plead,
But we that see his vain untoward course,
Cannot but fly the fire before it burn,
And shun the Court before we see his fall.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Will you not stay? then Lordings fare you well.
Though you forsake your King, the heavens I hope
Will favour him through mine incessant prayer.

sp.speaker: Dwar.
sp.l: Content you Madam, thus old Ouid sings.
It is foolish to bewail recureless things.

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Peace Dwarf, these words my patience move.

sp.speaker: Dwar.
sp.l: Although you charm my speech, charm not my love

div1.stage: Enter the King of Scots, Arius, the nobles spying him, returns.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Douglas how now? why changest thou thy cheer?

sp.speaker: Dougl.
sp.l: My private troubles are so great my liege,
As I must crave your licence for a while:
For to intend mine own affairs at home.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You may depart, but why is Morton sad?

sp.speaker: Mor.
sp.l: The like occasion doth import me too,
So I desire your grace to give me leave.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Well sir you may betake you to your ease,
When such grim sirs are gone, I see no let
To work my will.

sp.speaker: S. Atten.
sp.l: What like the Eagle then,
With often flight wilt thou thy feathers loose?
O King canst thou endure to see thy Court,
Of finest wits and Judgments dispossessed,
Whilst cloaking craft with soothing climbs so high,
As each bewails ambition is so bad?
Thy father left thee with estate and Crown,
A learned council to direct thy Court,
These carelessly O King thou castest off,
To entertain a train of Sycophants:
Thou well mayst see, although thou wilt not see,
That every eye and ear both sees and hears
The certain signs of thine incontinence:
Thou art allied unto the English King,
By marriage a happy friend indeed,
If used well, if not a mighty foe.
Thinketh your grace he can endure and brooke,
To have a partner in his daughters love?
Thinketh your grace the grudge of privy wrongs
Will not procure him change his smiles to threats?
O be not blind to good, call home your Lords,
Displace these flattering Gnatoes, drive them hence:
Love and with kindness take your wedlock wife
Or else (which God forbid) I fear a change,
Sin cannot thrive in courts without a plague.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Go pack thou too, unless thou mend thy talk:
On pain of death proud Bishop get you gone,
Unless you headless mean to hop away.

sp.speaker: 8. Atten.
sp.l: Thou god of heaven prevent my countries fall.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: These stays and lets to pleasure, plague my thoughts,
Forcing my grievous wounds anew to bleed:
Bur care that hath transported me so far,
Fair Ida is dispersed in thought of thee:
Whose answer yields me life, or breeds my death:
Yond comes the messenger of weal or woe.
Ateukin What news?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: The adamant o King will not be filled,
But by itself, and beauty that exceeds,
By some exceeding favour must be wrought,
Ida is coy as yet, and doth repine,
Objecting marriage, honour, fear, and death,
She is holy, wise, and too precise for me.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Are these thy fruits of wits, thy sight in Art?
Thine eloquence? thy policy? thy drift?
To mock thy Prince, then Caitiff pack thee hence,
And let me die devoured in my love.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Good Lord how rage gainsayeth reasons power,
My dear, my gracious, and beloved Prince,
The essence of my suit, my God on earth,
Sit down and rest yourself, appease your wrath,
Lest with a frown ye wound me to the death:
O that I were included in my grave,
That either now to save my Princes life,
Must counsel cruelty, or lose my King.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Why sirrah, is there means to move her mind?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: O should I not offend my royal liege.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Tell all, spare naught, so I may gain my love.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Alas my soul why art thou torn in twain,
For fear thou talk a thing that should displease?

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Tut, speak whatso thou wilt I pardon thee.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: How kind a word, how courteous is his grace:
Who would not die to succour such a king?
My liege, this lovely maid of modest mind,
Could well incline to love, but that she fears,
Fair Dorotheas power, your grace doth know,
Your wedlock is a mighty let to love:
Were Ida sure to be your wedded wife,
That then the twig would bow, you might command.
Ladies love, presents pomp and high estate.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Ah Ateukin, how should we display this let?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Tut mighty Prince, O that I might be whist.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Why dalliest thou?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: I will not move my Prince,
I will prefer his safety before my life:
Hear me O king, it is Dorotheas death,
Must do you good.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: What, murther of my Queen?
Yet to enjoy my love, what is my Queen?
O but my vow and promise to my Queen:
Aye but my hope to gain a fairer Queen,
With how contrarious thoughts am I withdrawn?
Why linger I twixt hope and doubtful fear:
If Dorothe die, will Ida love?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: She will my Lord.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Then let her die.
Devise, advise the means,
All likes me well that lends me hope in love.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: What will your grace consent, then let me work:
There is here in Court a Frenchman Iaques called,
A fit performer of our enterprise,
Whom I by gifts and promise will corrupt,
To slay the Queen, so that your grace will seal
A warrant for the man to save his life.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Naught shall he want, write thou and I will sign
And gentle Gnato, if my Ida yield,
Thou shalt have what thou wilt, I will give thee straight,
A Barony, an Earldom for reward.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Frolic young king, the Lass shall be your own,
I will make her blithe and wanton by my wit.

sp.speaker: Boh.
sp.l: So Oberon, now it begins to work in kind,
The ancient Lords by leaving him alive,
Disliking of his humours and respite,
Lets him run headlong till his flatterers,
Sweating his thoughts of luckless lust,
With vile persuasions and alluring words,
Makes him make way by murther to his will,
Judge fame king, hast heard a greater ill?

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: Nor send more virtue in a country maid,
I tell the Bohan it doth make me merry,
To think the deeds the king means to perform.

sp.speaker: Boha.
sp.l: To change that humour stand and see the rest,
I trow my son Slipper will show us a jest.

div1.stage: Enter Slipper with a companion, bog, or wench, dancing a hornpipe, and dance out again.

sp.speaker: Boha.
sp.l: Now after this beguiling of our thoughts,
And changing them from sad to better glee,
Let us to our sell, and sit and see thee rest,
For I believe this Jig will prove no jest.

div1.head: Chorus Actus 3. Schena Prima.
div1.stage: Enter Slipper one way, and S. Bartram another way.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Ho fellow, stay and let me speak with thee.

sp.speaker: Sli.
sp.p: Fellow, friend thou dost disabuse me, I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A Gentleman how so?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why I rub horses sir.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And what of that?

sp.speaker: Sip.
sp.p: O simple witted, mark my reason, they that do good service in the Common-weal are Gentlemen, but such as rub horses do good service in the Common-weal, Ergo tarbox Master Courtier, a Horse-keeper is a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Here is overmuch wit in good earnest:
But sirrah where is thy Master?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Neither above ground nor down ground,
Drawing out red into white,
Swallowing that down without chewing,
That was never made without treading.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Why where is he then?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Why in his seller, drinking a cup of neat and brisk claret, in a bowl of silver: O sir the wine runs trillill down
his throat, which cost the poor vintner many a stamp before it was made: but I must hence sir, I have haste.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why whither now I prithee?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Faith sir, to Sir Siluester a Knight hard by, upon my Masters errand, whom I must certify this, that the lease of Est Spring shall be confirmed, and therefore must I bid him provide trash, for my Master is no friend without money.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: This is the thing for which I sued so long,
This is the lease which I by Gnatoes means,
Sought to possess by patent from the King:
But he injurious man, who lives by crafts,
And sells kings favours for who will give most,
Hath taken bribes of me, yet covertly
Will sell away the thing pertains to me:
But I have found a present help I hope,
For to prevent his purpose and deceit:
Stay gentle friend.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: A good word, thou hast won me,
This word is like a warm candle to a cold stomach.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Sirrah wilt thou for money and reward,
Convey me certain letters out of hand,
From out thy masters pocket.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Will I sir, why, were it to rob my father, hang my mother, or any such like trifles, I am at your
commandment sir, what will you give me sir?

sp.speaker: S. Bar.
sp.p: A hundredth pounds.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I am your man, give me earnest, I am dead at a pocket sir, why I am a lifter master, by my occupation.

sp.speaker: S. Bar.
sp.p: A lifter, what is that?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why sir, I can lift a pot as well as any man, and pick a purse as soon as any thief in my country.

sp.speaker: S. Bar.
sp.l: Why fellow hold, here is earnest,
Ten pound to assure thee, go dispatch,
And bring it me to yonder Tavern thou seest,
And assure thyself thou shalt both have
Thy skin full of wine, and the rest of thy money.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I will sir. Now room for a Gentleman, my masters, who gives me money for a fair new Angel, a trim new Angel?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Sirrah, I must needs have your masters horses,
The king cannot be unserved.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sirrah you must needs go without them,
Because my Master must be served.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Why I am the kings Purveyor,
And I tell thee I will have them.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I am Ateukins servant, Seignior Andrew,
And I say thou shalt not have them.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Here is my ticket, deny it if thou darest.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: There is the stable, fetch them out if thou darest.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah, tame your tongue, lest I make you.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah, hold your hand, lest I bum you.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I tell thee, thy Masters geldings are good,
And therefore fit for the king.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: I tell thee, my Masters horses have galled backs,
And therefore cannot fit the King.
sp.p:
Purveyor, Purveyor, purvey thee of more wit, darest thou presume
to wrong my Lord Ateukins, being the chiefest man in Court.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: The more unhappy Common-weal,
Where flatterers are chief in Court.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: I say thou art too presumptuous,
And the officers shall school thee.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: A fig for them and thee Purveyor,
They seek a knot in a ring, that would wrong
My master or his servants in this Court.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: The world is at a wise pass,
When Nobility is afraid of a flatterer.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Sirrah, what be you that parley, contra Monsieur my Lord Ateukin, en bonne foy, prate you against sir Altesse, me maka your test to leap from your shoulders, per ma foy cy fere ie.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: O seignior Captain, you show yourself a forward and friendly Gentleman in my Masters behalf, I will cause him to thank you.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Poultron speak me one parola against my bon Gentilhome, I shall estrampe your guts, and thump your back, that you no point manage this ten hours.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: Sirrah come open me the stable,
And let me have the horses:
And fellow, for all your French brags I will do my duty.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: I will make garters of thy guts,
Thou villain if thou enter this office.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Mort lieu, take me that cappa
Pour nostre labeur, be gone villain in the mort.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.l: What will you resist me then?
Well the Council fellow, Shall know of your insolency.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Tell them what thou wilt, and eat that I can best spare from my back parts, and get you gone with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.p: Andrew.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.p: Where be my writings I put in my pocket last night.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Which sir, your annotations upon Matchauell?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.p: No sir, the letters patents for east spring.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Why sir you talk wonders to me, if you ask that question.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.p: Yea sir, and will work wonders too, which you unless you find them out, villain search me them out and bring them me, or thou art but dead.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: A terrible word in the latter end of a sessions. Master were you in your right wits yesternight?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.p: Dost thou doubt it?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p:
Aye and why not sir, for the greatest Clerks are not the wisest, and a fool may dance in a hood, as well as a wise man in a bare frock: besides such as give themselves to Plulantia, as you
do master, are so choleric of complexion, that that which they burn in fire overnight, they seek for with fury the next morning. Ah I take care of your worship, this common-weal should have a great loss of so good a member as you are.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Thou flatterest me.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Is it flattery in me sir to speak you fair?
What is it then in you to dally with the King?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Are you prating knave,
I will teach you better nurture?
Is this the care you have of my wardrobe?
Of my accounts, and matters of trust?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.p: Why alas sir, in times past your garments have been so well inhabited, as your Tenants would give no place to a Moth to mangle them, but since you are grown greater and your Garments more fine and gay, if your garments are not fit for hospitality, blame your pride, and commend my cleanliness: as for your writings, I am not for them, nor they for me.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Villain go, fly, find them out:
If thou loosest them, thou loosest my credit.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Alas sir? can I lose that you never had.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Say you so, then hold feel you that you never felt.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.l: O Monsieur, ayes patient, pardon your poor valet,
Me be at your commandment.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Seignior Iaques well met, you shall command me,
Sirrah go cause my writings be proclaimed in the Market place,
Promise a great reward to them that finds them,
Look where I supped and everywhere.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: I will sir, now are two knaves well met, and three well parted, if you conceive mine enigma, Gentlemen what shall I be then, faith a plain harp shilling.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Sieut, Iaques, this our happy meeting hides,
Your friends and me, of care and grievous toil,
For I that look into deserts of men,
And see among the soldiers in this court,
A noble forward mind, and judge thereof,
Cannot but seek the means to raise them up:
Who merit credit in the Common-weal.
To this intent friend Iaque I have found
A means to make you great, and well esteemed
Both with the king, and with the best in Court:
For I espy in you a valiant mind,
Which makes me love, admire, and honour you:
To this intent (if so your trust and faith,
Your secrecy be equal with your force)
I will impart a service to thyself,
Which if thou dost effect, the King, myself,
And what or he, and I with him can work,
Shall be employed in what thou wilt desire.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Me swear by my ten bones, my seignior, to be loyal to your Lordships intents, affairs, yea my monsignor, qui non fera ic pour. Your pleasure?
sp.l: By my sword me be no baby Lords.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Then hoping on thy truth, I prithee see,
How kind Ateukin is to forward me,
Hold take this earnest penny of my love.
And mark my words, the King by me requires,
No slender service Iaques at thy hands.
Thou must by privy practise make away,
The Queen fair Dorethea as she sleeps:
Or how thou wilt, so she be done to death:
Thou shalt not want promotion here in Court.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Stab the woman, per ma foy, monsignor, me thrust my weapon into her belle, so me may be guard per le roy.
sp.l: Me do your service.
But me no be hanged per my labour.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Thou shalt have warrant Iaques from the King,
None shall outface, gainsay and wrong my friend.
Do not I love thee Iaques? fear not then,
I tell thee who so toucheth thee in aught,
Shall injure me, I love, I tender thee:
Thou art a subject fit to serve his grace,
Iaques, I had a written warrant once,
But that by great misfortune late is lost,
Come wend we to Saint Andrewes, where his grace
Is now in progress, where he shall assure
Thy safety, and confirm thee to the act.

sp.speaker: Iaques.
sp.l: We will attend your nobleness.

div1.stage: Enter sir Bartram, Dorothea, the Queen, Nano, Lord Ross. Ladies attendants.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Thy credit Bartram in the Scottish Court,,
Thy reverend years, the strictness of thy vows,
All these are means sufficient to persuade,
But love the faithful link of loyal hearts,
That hath possession of my constant mind,
Exiles all dread, subdueth vain suspect,
Methinks no craft should harbour in that breast,
Where Majesty and virtue is installed:
Methink my beauty should not cause my death.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: How gladly sovereign Princess would I err,
And bind my shame to save your royal life:
It is Princely in yourself to think the best,
To hope his grace is guiltless of this crime,
But if in due prevention you default,
How blind are you that were forewarned before.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Suspicion without cause deserveth blame.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Who sees, and shun not harms, deserve the same:
Behold the tenor of this traitorous plot.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: What should I read? Perhaps he wrote it not.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Here is his warrant under seal and sign,
To Iaques born in France to murther you.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Ah careless King, would God this were not thine
What though I read? Ah should I think it true?

sp.speaker: Rosse.
sp.l: The hand and seal confirms the deed is his.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: What know I though, if now he thinketh this?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Madam Lucretius saith, that to repent,
Is shildish wisdom to prevent.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: What though?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Then cease your tears, that have dismayed you,
And cross the foe before he have betrayed you.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: What needs this long suggestions in this cause?
When every circumstance confirmeth truth:
First let the hidden mercy from above,
Confirm your grace, since by a wondrous means,
The practise of your dangers came to light:
Next let the tokens of appeared truth,
Govern and stay your thoughts, too much seduced,
And mark the sooth, and listen the intent,
Your highness knows, and these my noble Lords,
Can witness this, that whilst your husbands sire
In happy peace possessed the Scottish Crown,
I was his sworn attendant here in Court,
In dangerous fight I never failed my Lord.
And since his death, and this your husbands reign,
No labour, duty, have I left undone,
To testify my zeal unto the Crown:
But now my limbs are weak, mine eyes are dim,
Mine age unwieldy and unmeet for toil:
I came to court in hope for service past,
To gain some lease to keep me being old,
There found I all was upsy turvy turned,
My friends displacest, the Nobles loath to crave,
Then sought I to the minion of the King,
Auteukin, who allured by a bribe,
Assured me of the lease for which I sought:
But see the craft, when he had got the grant,
He wrought to sell it to Sir Siluester,
In hope of greater earnings from his hands:
In brief, I learnt his craft, and wrought the means,
By one his needy servants for reward,
To steal from out his pocket all the briefs,
Which he performed, and with reward resigned
Them when I read (now mark the power of God)
I found this warrant sealed among the rest,
To kill your grace, whom God long keep alive.
Thus in effect, by wonder are you saved,
Trifle not then, but seek a speakie flight,
God will conduct your steppes, and shield the right.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What should I do, ah poor unhappy Queen?
born to endure what fortune can contain,
Alas the deed is too apparent now:
But O mine eyes were you as bent to hide,
As my poor heart is forward to forgive.
Ah cruel king, my love would thee acquit,
O what avails to be allied and matched
With high estates that marry but in show?
Were I baser born, my mean estate
Could warrant me from this impendent harm,
But to be great and happy these are twain.
Ah Rosse what shall I do, how shall I work?

sp.speaker: Rosse.
sp.l: With speedy letters to your father send,
Who will revenge you, and defend your right.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: As if they kill not me, who with him fight?
As if his breast be touched, I am not wounded,
As if he wailed, my joys were not confounded:
We are one heart, though rent by hate in twain:
One soul, one essence doth our weal contain:
What then can conquer him that kills not me?

sp.speaker: Rosse.
sp.l: If this advice displease, then Madam flee.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Where may I wend or travel without fear?

sp.speaker: No.
sp.l: Where not, in changing this attire you wear?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What shall I clad me like a Country maid?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: The policy is base I am afraid.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why Nano?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Ask you why? what may a Queen
March forth in homely weed and be not seen?
The Rose although in thorny shrubs she spread,
Is still the Rose, her beauties wax not dead.
And noble minds although the coat be bare,
Are by their semblance known, how great they are

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: The Dwarf saith true.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What garments likest thou then?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Such as may make you seem a proper man.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: He makes me blush and smile, though I am sad.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: The meanest coat for safety is not bad.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What shall I jet in breeches like a squire?
Alas poor dwarf, thy Mistress is unmeet.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Tut, go me thus, your cloak before your face,
Your sword upreared with quaint and comely grace,
If any come and question what you be,
Say you a man, and call for witness me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What should I wear a sword, to what intent?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Madam for show, it is an ornament,
If any wrong you, draw a shining blade
Withdraws a coward thief that would invade.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: But if I strike, and he should strike again,
What should I do? I fear I should be slain.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: No, take it single on your dagger so,
I will teach you Madam how to ward a blow.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: How little shapes much substance may include?
Sir Bartram, Rosse, ye Ladies and my friends,
Since presence yields me death, and absence life,
Hence will I fly disguised like a squire,
As one that seeks to live in Irish wars,
You gentle Rosse, shall furnish my depart.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: Yea Prince, and die with you with all my heart,
Vouchsafe me then in all extremest states,
To wait on you and serve you with my best.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To me pertains the woe, live then in rest:
Friends fare you well, keep secret my depart,
Nano alone shall my attendant be.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.l: Then Madam are you manned, I warrant ye,
Give me a sword, and if there grow debate,
I will come behind, and break your enemies pate.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: How sore we grieve to part so soon away.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Grieve not for those that perish if they stay.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: The time in words misspent, is little worth,
Madam walk on, and let them bring us forth.
So these sad motions makes the fair sleep,
And sleep he shall in quiet and content,
For it would make a marble melt and weep
To see these treasons against the innocent:
But since she scapes by flight to save her life,
The king may chance repent she was his wife:
The rest is ruthful, yet to beguiled the time,
It is interlaced with merriment and rhyme.

div1.head: Actus Quartus. Schena Prima.
div1.stage: After a noise of horns and showings, enter certaine Huntsmen, if you please, singing one way: another way Ateukin and Iaques, Gnato.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Say Gentlemen, where may we find the king?

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: Even here at hand on hunting.
And at this hour he taken hath a stand,
To kill a Deer.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: A pleasant work in hand,
Follow your sport, and we will seek his grace.

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: When such him seek, it is a woeful case.

div1.stage: Exeunt Huntsman one way, Ateu. and Iaq. another, Enter Eustace, Ida, and the Countess.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Lord Eustace, as your youth and virtuous life,
Deserves a fair, more fair, and richer wife,
So since I am a mother, and do wit
What wedlock is, and that which longs to it,
Before I mean my daughter to bestow,
It were meet that she and I your state did know.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Madam if I consider Idas worth,
I know my portions merit none so fair,
And yet I hold in farm and yearly rent,
A thousand pound, which may her state content.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: But what estate my Lord shall she possess?

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: All that is mine, grave Countess and no less.
But Ida will you love?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: I cannot hate.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: But will you wed?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: It is Greek to me my Lord,
I will wish you well, and thereon take my word.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Shall I some sign of favour then receive?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Aye, if her Ladyship will give me leave.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Do what thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Then noble English Peer,
Accept this ring, wherein my heart is set,
A constant heart, with burning flames befret:
But under written this: O morte dura:
Hereon when so you look with eyes Pura,
The maid you fancy most will favour you.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: I will try this heart, in hope to find it true.

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: Widow Countess well met,
Ever may thy joys be many,
Gentle Ida fair beset,
Fair and wise, not fairer any:
Frolic Huntsmen of the game,
Wills you well, and gives you greeting.

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Thanks good Woodman for the same,
And our sport and merry meeting.

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: Unto thee we do present,
Silver heart with arrow wounded.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: This doth shadow my lament,
Both fear and love confounded.

sp.speaker: Ladies.
sp.l: To the mother of the maid,
Fair as the lilies, red as roses,
Even so many goods are said,
As herself in heart supposes.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: What are you friends, that thus doth wish us well?

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: Your neighbours nigh, that have on hunting been,
Who understanding of your walking forth,
Prepare this train to entertain you with,
This Lady Douglas, this Sir Egmond is.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.l: Welcome ye Ladies, and thousand thanks for this,
Come enter you a homely widows house,
And if mine entertainment please you let us feast.

sp.speaker: Hunts.
sp.l: A lovely lady never wants a guest.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Stay gentle Ida, tell me what you deem,
What doth this haste, this tender heart beseem?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Why not my Lord, since nature teacheth art,
To senseless beasts to cure their grievous smart.
Dictanum serves to close the wound again.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: What help for those that love?

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Why love again.

sp.speaker: Eust.
sp.l: Were I the Heart,

sp.speaker: Ida
sp.l: Then I the herb would be.
You shall not die for help, come follow me.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Mon Deiu, what malheure be this, me come a the chamber, Seignior Andrew, Mon Deiu, take my poniard en mon maine, to give the Estocade to the Damoisella, per ma foy, there was no person, elle cest en alle.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
The worse luck Iaques, but because I am thy friend I will advise thee somewhat towards the attainment of the
gallows.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Gallows, what be that?

sp.speaker: An.
