sp.p: Marry sir, a place of great promotion, where thou shalt by one turn above ground, rid the world of a knave, and make a goodly example for all bloody villains of thy profession. Que ditte vous, Monsieur Andrew?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: I say Iaques, thou must keep this path, and high thee, for the Queen as I am certified, is departed with her dwarf, apparelled like a squire, overtake her Frenchman, stab her, I will promise thee this doublet shall be happy.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Purquoy?

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: It shall serve a jolly Gentleman,
Sir Dominus Mon seignior Hangman.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Cest tout, vn me will rama pour le monoy.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p:
Go, and the rot consume thee? O what a trim world is this? My master lives by cozening the king, I by flattering him: Slipper my fellow by stealing: and I by lying: is not this a wily accord, Gentlemen. This last night our jolly horse-keeper being well stepped in liquor, confessed to me the stealing of
my Masters writings, and his great reward: now dare I not bewray him, lest he discover my knavery, but thus have I wrought: I understand he will pass this way, to provide him necessaries, but if I and my fellows fail not, we will teach him such a lesson, as shall cost him a chief place on penniless bench for his labour: but yond he comes.

div1.stage: Enter Slipper with a Tailor, a Shoemaker, and a Cutler.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Let my doublet be white Northern, five groats the yard, I tell thee I will be brave.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: It shall sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Now sir, cut it me like the battlements of a Custard, full of round holes: edge me the sleeves with Coventry blue, and let the linings be of tenpenny locorum.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Very good sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Make it the amorous cut, a flap before.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: And why so? that fashion is stale.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: O friend, thou art a simple fellow, I tell thee, a flap is a great friend to a story, it stands him instead of clean napery, and if a man's shirt be torn, it is a present penthouse to defend him from a clean housewife's scoff.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: You say sooth sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Hold take thy money, there is seven shillings for the doublet, and eight for the breeches, seven and eight, biladio thirty six is a save deal of money.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Nay but stay Taylor.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Why sir?

sp.speaker: Slipper.
sp.l: Forget not this special mate,
Let my back parts be well lined,
For there come many winter storms from a windy belly,
I tell thee Shoemaker.

sp.speaker: Shoe-ma.
sp.p: Gentleman what shoe will it please you to have?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: A fine neat calves leather my friend.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.p: O sir, that is too thin, it will not last you.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
I tell thee, it is my near kinsman, for I am Slipper, which hath his best grace in summer to be suited in lakus skins, Guidwife Clarke was my Grandmother, and Goodman Neatherleather mine Uncle, but my mother good woman. Alas, she was a Spaniard, and being well tanned and dressed by a good-fellow, an Englishman, is grown to some wealth: as when I have but my upper parts, clad in her husbands costly Spanish
leather, I may be bold to kiss the fairest Ladies foot in this country.

sp.speaker: Shoo.
sp.l: You are of high birth sir,
But have you all your mothers marks on you?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Why knave?

sp.speaker: Shoemaker.
sp.p: Because if thou come of the blood of the Slippers, you should have a Shoemakers Awl thrust through your ear.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: Take your earnest friend and be packing,
And meddle not with my progenitors Cutler.

sp.speaker: Cutler.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.l: I must have a Rapier and Dagger.

sp.speaker: Cutler.
sp.l: A Rapier and Dagger you mean sir?

sp.speaker: Slipper.
sp.l: Thou sayst true, but it must have a very fair edge,

sp.speaker: Cutler.
sp.l: Why so sir?

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Because it may cut by himself, for truly my friend, I am a man of peace, and wear weapons but for fashion.

sp.speaker: Cutler.
sp.p: Well sir, give me earnest I will fit you.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Hold take it, I betrust thee friend, let me be well armed.

sp.speaker: Cutler.
sp.p: You shall.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Now what remains? there is twenty Crowns for house, three crowns for household stuff, six pence to buy a Constables staff: nay I will be the chief of my parish, there wants nothing but a wench, a cat, a dog, a wife and a servant, to make an hole family, shall I marry with Alice, good ma Grimshaues daughter, she is fair, but indeed her tongue is like Clocks on Shrove tuesday, always out of temper? shall I wed Sisley of the Whighte? O, no she is like a frog in a parsley bed, as skittish as an eel, if I seek to hamper her, she will horn me: but a wench must be had master Slip. Yea and shall be dear friend.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.p: I now will drive him from his contemplations. O my mates come forward, the lamb is unpent, the fox shall prevail.

div1.stage: Enter three Antiques, who dance round, and take Slipper with them.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: I will my friend, and I thank you heartily, pray keep your courtesy, I am yours in the way of an hornpipe, they are strangers, I see they understand not my language, wee wee.

div1.stage: Whilst they are dancing, Andrew takes away his money, and the other Antiques depart.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Nay but my friends, one hornpipe, further a refluence back, and two doubles forward: what not one cross point against
Sundays. What ho sirrah, you gone, you with the nose like an Eagle, and you be a right greek, one turn more, thieves thieves, I am robbed thieves. Is this the knavery of Fiddlers? Well, I will then bind the hole credit of their occupation on a bagpiper, and he for my money, but I will after, and teach them to caper in a halter, that have cozened me of my money.

div1.stage: Enter Nano, Dorothea, in man's apparel.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Ah Nano, I am weary of these weeds,
Weary to wield this weapon that I bare:
Weary of love, from whom my woe proceeds.
Weary of toil, since I have lost my dear,
O weary life, where wanted no distress,
But every thought is paid with heaviness.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Too much of weary Madam, if you please,
Sit down, let weary die, and take your ease.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: How look I Nano like a man or no?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: If not a man, yet like a manly shrew.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: If any come and meet us on the way,
What should we do if they enforce us stay.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Set cap a huff, and challenge him the field,
Suppose the worst, the weak may fight to yield.

sp.speaker: Dorot.
sp.l: The battle Nano in this troubled mind,
Is far more fierce than ever we may find.
The bodies wounds by medicines may be eased,
But griefs of minds, by salves are not appeased.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Say Madam, will you hear your Nano sing?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Of woe good boy, but of no other thing:

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: What if I sing of fancy will it please?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: To such as hope success, such notes breed ease.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: What if I sing like Damon to my sheep?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Like Phillis I will sit me down to weep.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Nay since my songs afford such pleasure small,
I will sit me down, and sing you none at all.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: O be not angry Nano.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Nay you loath,
To think on that, which doth content us both.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: And how?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: You scorn disport when you are weary,
And loath my mirth, who live to make you merry.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Danger and fear withdraw me from delight.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: It is virtue to contemn false Fortunes spite.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: What should I do to please thee friendly squire?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: A smile a day, is all I will require:
And if you pay me well the smiles you owe me,
I will kill this cursed care, or else beshrew me.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: We are descried, O Mano we are dead.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Tut yet you walk, you are not dead indeed,
Draw me your sword, if he your way withstand.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: And I will seek for rescue out of hand,
Run Nano run, prevent thy Princes death.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Fear not, I will run all danger out of breath.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Ah you calletta, you strumpet, ta Matressa Doretie este, vous surprius come say your pater noster, car vous est mort par ma foy

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Callet, me strumpet, Caitiff as thou art
But even a Princess born, who scorn thy threats.
Shall never French man say, an English maid,
Of threats of foreign force will be afraid.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: You no dire vostre prieges, vrbleme merchants famme, guarda your bresta, there me make you die on my mor glay,

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: God shield me hapless princes and a wife.
sp.stage: They fight, and she is sore wounded.
sp.l: And save my soul, although I lose my life.
Ah I am slain, some piteous power repay,
This murtherers cursed deed, that doth me slay.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Elle est tout mort, me will run per a wager, for fear me be surprise and pendu for my labour. Be in Ie meu alera au roy
auy cits me affaires, Ie ferra vn chiualier, for this days travail.

div1.stage: Enter Nano, S. Cutbert Anderson, his sword drawne.

sp.speaker: S. Cuth.
sp.l: Where is this poor distressed gentleman?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Here laid on ground, and wounded to the death.
Ah gentle heart, how are these beauteous looks,
Dimmed by the tyrant cruelties of death:
O weary soul, break thou from forth my breast,
And join thee with the soul I honoured most.

sp.speaker: S. Cut.
sp.l: Leave mourning friend, the man is yet alive,
Some help me to convey him to my house:
There will I see him carefully recured,
And send privy search to catch the murtherer.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: The God of heaven reward the courteous knight.

div1.stage: Exeunt. And they bear out Dorothea.
Enter the King of Scots, Iaques, Ateukin, Andrew, Iaques running with his sword one way the King with his train an other way.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Stay Iaques, fear not, sheath thy murthering blade:
Lo here thy King and friends are come abroad,
To save thee from the terrors of pursuit:
What is she dead?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Wee Monsieur, elle is blesse per lake teste, ones les espanles, I warrant she no trouble you.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: O then my liege, how happy art thou grown,
How favoured of the heavens, and blessed by love:
Methinks I see fair Ida in thine arms,
Craving remission for her late attempt,
Methink I see her blushing steal a kiss:
Uniting both your souls by such a sweet,
And you my King suck Nectar from her lips.
Why then delays your grace to gain the rest
You long desired? why lose we forward time?
Write, make me spokesman now, vow marriage,
If she deny your favour let me die.

sp.speaker: Andy.
sp.p: Mighty and magnificent potentate, give credence to mine honourable good Lord, for I heard the Midwife swear at his nativity, that the Fairies gave him the property of the Thracian stone, for who toucheth it, is exempted from grief, and he that heareth my Masters counsel, is already possessed of happiness: nay which is more miraculous, as the Noble man in his infancy lay in his Cradle, a swarm of Bees laid honey on his lips, in token of his eloquence. For melle dulcier fluit oratio.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Your grace must bear with imperfections:
This is exceeding love that makes him speak.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Ateukin I am ravished in conceit,
And yet depressed again with earnest thoughts,
Methinks this murther soundeth in mine ear,
A threatening noise of dire and sharp revenge.
I am incensed with grief, yet fain would joy,
What may I do to end me of these doubts?

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Why Prince it is no murther in a King,
To end another's life to save his own,
For you are not as common people be.
Who die and perish with a few man's tears,
But if you fail, the state doth whole default
The Realm is rent in twain, in such a loss.
And Aristotle holdeth this for true,
Of evils needs we must choose the least,
Then better were it, that a woman died,
Than all the help of Scotland should be blent,
It is policy my liege, in every state,
To cut off members that disturb the head.
And by corruption generation grows.
And contraries maintain the world and state.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Enough I am confirmed, Ateukin come,
Rid me of love, and rid me of my grief,
Drive thou the tyrant from this tainted breast.
Then may I triumph in the height of joy,
Go to mine Ida, tell her that I vow,
To raise her head and make her honours great.
Go to mine Ida, tell her that her hairs,
Shall be embellished with orient pearls,
And Crowns of Sapphires compassing her brows,
Shall wear with those sweet beauties of her eyes.
Go to mine Ida, tell her that my soul
Shall keep her semblance closed in my breast,
And I in touching of her milk-white mold,
Will think me deified in such a grace:
I like no stay, go write and I will sign.
Reward me Iaques, give him store of Crown.
And sirrah Andrew, scout thou here in Court:
And bring me tidings if thou canst perceive
The least intent of muttering in my train,
For either those that wrong thy Lord or thee,
Shall suffer death.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: How much O mighty king,
Is thy Ateukin bound to honour thee:
Bow thee Andrew, bend thine sturdy knees,
Seest thou not here thine only God on earth?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Mes on est mon argent Signior.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Come follow me, his grave I see is made,
That thus on sudden he hath left us here.
Come Iaques, we will have our packet soon dispatched
And you shall be my mate upon the way.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.l: Come vous plera Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Was never such a world I think before,
When sinners seem to dance within a net,
The flatterer and the murtherer they grow big,
By hook or crook promotion now is sought,
In such a world where men are so misled,
What should I do? but as the Proverb saith,
Run with the Hare, and hunt with the Hound.
To have two means, beseems a witty man:
Now here in Court I may aspire and clime,
By subtlety for my masters death.
And if that fail, well fare another drift:
I will in secret certain letters send
Unto the English King, and let him know
The order of his daughters overthrow.
That if my master crack his credit here,
As I am sure long flattery cannot hold,
I may have means within the English Court
To scape the scourge that waits on bad advice.

div1.head: Chorus.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: Believe me bonny Scot, these strange events,
Are passing pleasing, may they end as well.

sp.speaker: Boha.
sp.l: Else say that Bohan hath a barren skull,
If better motions yet than any past,
Do not more glee to make the fairy greet,
But my small son made pretty handsome shift,
To save the Queen his Mistress by his speed.

sp.speaker: Obiro.
sp.l: Yea you Lady for his sport he made,
Shall see when least he hopes, I will stand his friend,
Or else he capers in a halters end.

sp.speaker: Boha.
sp.l: What hang my son? I trow not Obiran:
I will rather die, than see him woe begone.

div1.stage: Enter a round, or some dance at Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Ober.
sp.l: Bohan be pleased, for do they what they will,
Here is my hand, I will save thy son from ill.

div1.head: Actus Quintus. Schena Prima.
div1.stage: Enter the Queen in a night gowne, Lady Anderson, and Nano.

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: My gentle friend beware in taking air,
Your walks grow not offensive to your wounds.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Madam I thank you of your courteous care,
My wounds are well nigh closed, though sore they are.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: Methinks these closed wounds should breed more grief,
Since open wounds have cure, and find relief.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Madam, if undiscovered wounds you mean,
They are not cured, because they are not seen.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: I mean the wounds which do the heart subdue.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: O that is love, Madam speak I not true?

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: Say it were true, what salve for such a sore?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Be wise, and shut such neighbours out of door.

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: How if I cannot drive him from my breast?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Then chain him well, and let him do his best.

sp.speaker: S. Cuth.
sp.l: In ripping up their wounds, I see their wit,
But if these wounds be cured I sorrow it.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Why are you so intentive to behold,
My pale and woeful looks, by care controlled?

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: Because in them a ready way is found,
To cure my care, and heal my hidden wound.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Good Master shut your eyes, keep that conceit,
Surgeons give Coin, to get a good receipt.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Peace wanton son, this Lady did amend
My wounds: mine eyes her hidden grief shall end,
Look not too much, it is a weighty case.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Whereas a man puts on a maidens face,
For many times if Ladies wear them not,
A nine months wound with little work is got.

sp.speaker: S. Cuth.
sp.l: I will break off their dispute, lest love proceed,
From covert smiles, to perfect love indeed.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: The cat is abroad, stir not, the mice be still,

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: Tut, we can fly such cats when so we will.

sp.speaker: S. Cuth.
sp.l: How fares my guest, take cheer, naught shall default,
That either doth concern your health or joy,
Use me, my house, and what is mine is yours.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Thanks gentle knight, and if all hopes be true,
I hope ere long to do as much for you.

sp.speaker: S. Cuth.
sp.l: Your virtue doth acquit me of that doubt:
But courteous sir, since troubles calls me hence,
I must to Edenbourg unto the king,
There to take charge, and wait him in his wars:
Meanwhile good Madam take this squire in charge,
And use him so as if it were myself.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: Sir Cuthert doubt not of my diligence:
Meanwhile, till your return God send you health.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: God bless his grace, and if his cause be just,
Prosper his wars: if not he will mend I trust:
Good sir what moves the king to fall to arms?

sp.speaker: S. Cuth.
sp.l: The king of England forageth his land,
And hath besieged Dambac with mighty force:
What other news are common in the Court,
Read you these letters Madam tell the squire,
The whole affairs of state, for I must hence.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: God prosper you, and bring you back from thence:
Madam what news?

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: They say the Queen is slain.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Tut, such reports more false than truth contain.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: but these reports have made his Nobles leave him.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Ah careless men, and would they so deceive him?

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: The land is spoiled, the commons fear the cross,
All cry against the king, their cause of loss:
The English king subdues and conquers all.

sp.speaker: Doro,
sp.l: Alas, this war grows great, on causes small.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: Our Court is desolate, our Prince alone,
Still dreading death.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Woe is me, for him I moan,
Help, now help, a sudden qualm.
Assails my heart.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Good Madam stand her friend,
Give us some liquor to refresh her heart.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: Daw thou her up, and I will fetch thee forth
Potions of comfort to repress her pain.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Fie Princess, faint on every fond report,
How well nigh had you opened your estate:
Cover these sorrows with the vail of joy,
And hope the best for why this war will cause,
A great repentance in your husbands mind.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Ah Nano, trees live not without their sap,
And Clitia cannot blush but on the sun,
The thirsty earth is broke with many a gap,
And lands are lean, where rivers do not run,
Where soul is rest from that it loveth best,
How can it thrive or boast of quiet rest?
Thou knowest the Princes loss must be my death,
His grief, my grief: his mischief must be mine:
O if thou love me, Nano high to court,
Tell Rosse, tell Bartram that I am alive,
Conceal thou yet, the place of my abode,
Will them even as they love their Queen,
As they are chary of my soul and joy,
To guard the King, to serve him as my Lord:
Haste thee good Nana, for my husbands care,
Consumeth me and wounds me to the heart.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Madam I go, yet loath to leave you here.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Go thou with speed, even as thou holdest me dear,
Return in haste.

sp.speaker: L. An,
sp.l: Now sir, what cheer? come taste this broth I bring.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: My grief is past, I feel no further sting.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: Where is your dwarf? Why hath he left you sir?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: For some affairs, he is not travelled far.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: If so you please, come in and take your rest.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Fear keeps awake a discontented breast.

div1.stage: After a solemne service, enter from the widows house a service, musical songs of marriages, or a maske, or what pretty triumph you list, to them, Ateukin and Gnato.

sp.speaker: Ate,
sp.l: What means this triumph friend? why are these feasts?

sp.speaker: Serui.
sp.l: Fair Ida sir, was married yesterday,
Unto sir Eustace, and for that intent,
We feast and sport it thus to honour them:
And if you please, come in and take your part,
My Lady is no niggard of her cheer.

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p:
Monsignor, why be you so sadda, fette bon chere fontre
de ce monde.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: What? was I born to be the scorn of kin?
To gather feathers like to a hopper crow,
And lose them in the height of all my pomp:
Accursed man now is my credit lost:
Where is my vows I made unto the king?
What shall become of me, if he shall hear,
That I have caused him kill a virtuous Queen?
And hope in vain for that which now is lost:
Where shall I hide my head? I know the heavens
Are just, and will revenge: I know my sins
Exceed compare: should I proceed in this?
This Eustace must amain be made away:
O were I dead, how happy should I be?

sp.speaker: Iaq.
sp.p: Est ce donque a tell poynt vostre estat, faith then adieu Scotland, adieu Seignior Ateukin, me will home to France, and no be hanged in a strange country.

sp.speaker: Ateu.
sp.l: Thou dost me good to leave me thus alone,
That galling grief and I may yoke in one:
O what are subtle means to clime on high?
When every fall swarms with exceeding shame?
I promised Idaes love unto the Prince,
But she is lost, and I am false forsworn:
I practised Dorotheas hapless death,
And by this practise have commenced a war.
O cursed race of men that traffic guile,
And in the end, themselves and kings beguile:
Ashamed to look upon my Prince again:
Ashamed of my suggestions and advise:
Ashamed of life: a shamed that I have erred:
I will hide myself, expecting for my shame.
Thus God doth work with those, that purchase fame
By flattery, and make their Prince their game.

div1.stage: Enter the King of England, Lord Percey, Samles, and others.

sp.speaker: Arius,
sp.l: Thus far the English Peers have we displayed,
Our waving Ensigns with a happy war,
Thus nearly hath our furious rage revenged,
My daughters death upon the traitorous Scot,
And now before Dambar our camp is pitched,
Which if it yield not to our compromise,
The place shall furrow where the palace stood,
And fury shall envy so high a power,
That mercy shall be banished from our swords.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: What seeks the English King?

sp.speaker: Arius,
sp.l: Scot open those gates, and let me enter in,
Submit thyself and thine unto my grace,
Or I will put each mothers son to death,
And lay this City level with the ground.

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: For what offence? for what default of ours?
Art thou incensed so sore against our state?
Can generous hearts in nature be so stern
To pray on those that never did offend?
What though the lion, (king of brutish race,
Through outrage sin, shall lambs be therefore slain?
Or is it lawful that the humble die,
Because the mighty do gainsay the right?
O English King, thou bearest in thy breast,
The King of beasts, that harms not yielding ones,
The Roseall cross is spread within thy field,
A sign of peace, not of revenging war:
Be gracious then unto this little town,
And though we have withstood thee for a while,
To show allegiance to our liefest liege,
Yet since we know no hope of any help,
Take us to mercy, for we yield ourselves.

sp.speaker: Ari,
sp.l: What shall I enter then and be your Lord?

sp.speaker: Doug.
sp.l: We will submit us to the English king.

div1.stage: They descend down, open the gates, and humble them.

sp.speaker: Arius,
sp.l: Now life and death dependeth on my sword:
This hand now reared, my Douglas if I list,
Could part thy head and shoulders both in twain:
But since I see thee wise and old in years,
True to thy king, and faithful in his wars,
Live thou and thine, Dambar is too too small,
To give an entrance to the English king,
I Eagle-like disdain these little fowls,
And look on none but those that dare resist,
Enter your town as those that live by me,
For others that resist, kill, forage, spoil:
Mine English soldiers, as you love your king,
Revenge his daughters death, and do me right.

div1.stage: Enter the Lawyer, the Merchant, and the Divine.

sp.speaker: Lawyer.
sp.l: My friends, what think you of this present state,
Were ever seen such changes in a time?
The manners and the fashions of this age,
Are like the Ermine skin so full of spots,
As soon may the Moore be washed white,
Than these corruptions banished from this Realm.

sp.speaker: March.
sp.l: What sees master Lawyer in this state amiss?

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: A wrestling power that makes a nose of wax,
Of grounded law, a damned and subtle drift,
In all estates to clime by others loss,
An eager thrift of wealth, forgetting truth,
Might I ascend unto the highest states,
And by descent discover every crime,
My friends I should lament, and you would grieve
To see the hapless ruins of this Realm.

sp.speaker: Diu.
sp.l: O Lawyer, thou hast curious eyes to pry,
Into the secrets maims of their estate,
But if thy vail of error were unmasked,
Thyself should see your sect, do maim her most:
Are you not those that should maintain the peace,
Yet only are the patrons of our strife?
If your profession have his ground and spring,
First from the laws of God, then countries right,
Not any ways inverting natures power,
Why thrive you by contentions? Why devise you
Clauses, and subtle reasons to except:
Our state was first before you grew so great,
A Lantern to the world for unity:
Now they that are befriended, and are rich,
Or press the poor, come Homer without Coin,
He is not heard: What shall we term this drift?
To say the poor man's cause is good and just,
And yet the rich man gains the best in law:
It is your guise, (the more the world laments)
To quome Provisos to beguile your laws,
To make a gay pretext of due proceeding,
When you delay your common pleas for years:
Mark what these dealings lately here have wrought:
The crafty men have purchased great mens lands
They pull, they pinch, their tenants are undone:
If these complain by you they are undone,
You fleece them of their Coin, their children beg,
And many want, because you may be rich,
This scar is mighty master Lawyer,
Now man hath gotten head within this land,
Mark but the guise, the poor man that is wronged,
Is ready to rebel: he spoils, he pills,
We need no foes to forage that we have,
The law (say they) in peace consumed us,
And now in war we will consume the law:
Look to this mischief, Lawyers conscience knows
You live amiss, amend it, lest you end.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Good Lord, that their Divines should see so far
In others faults, without amending theirs?
Sir, sir, the general defaults in state,
(If you would read before you did correct)
Are by a hidden working from above,
By their successive changes still remained,
Were not the law by contraries maintained,
How could the truth from falsehood be discerned?
Did we not taste the bitterness of war?
How could we know the sweet effects of peace?
Did we not feel the nipping winter frosts,
How should we know the sweetness of the spring?
Should all things still remain in one estate,
Should not in greatest arts some scars be found,
Were all upright and changed, what world were this?
A Chaos, made of quiet, yet no world,
Because the parts thereof did still accord,
This matter craves a variance not a speech,
But sir Divine to you, look on your maims,
Divisions, sects, your summonies and bribes:
Your cloaking with the great, for fear to fall,
You shall perceive you are the cause of all.
Did each man know there were a storm at hand,
Who would not cloth him well, to shun the wet?
Did Prince and Peer, the Lawyer and the least,
Know what were sin, without a partial gloss,
We need no long discovery then of crimes,
For each would mend, advised by holy men:
Thus but slightly shadow out your sins,
But if they were depainted out for life,
Alas we both had wounds enough to heal.

sp.speaker: Merch.
sp.l: None of you both I see but are in fault,
Thus simple men as I do swallow flies,
This grave Divine can tell us what to do,
But we may say: Physician mend thyself,
This Lawyer hath a pregnant wit to talk,
But all are words, I see no deeds of worth.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Good Merchant lay your fingers on your mouth,
Be not a blab, for fear you bite yourself,
What should I term your state, but even the way
To every ruin in this Common-weal,
You bring us in the means of all excess,
You rate it and retailed it as you please,
You swear, forswear, and all to compass wealth,
Your money is your God, your hoard your heaven,
You are the ground work of contention:
First heedless youth, by you is overteached,
We are corrupted by your many crowns:
The Gentlemen, whose titles you have bought,
Lose all their fathers toil within a day,
Whilst Hob your son, and Sib your nut-brown child,
Are Gentle folks, and Gentles are beguiled:
This makes so many Noble maids to stray,
And take sinister courses in the state.

sp.speaker: Scout.
sp.l: My friends begone if you love your lives,
The King of England marcheth here at hand,
Enter the camp for fear you be surprised.

sp.speaker: Divine.
sp.l: Thanks gentle scout, God mend that is amiss,
And place true, zeal whereas corruption is.

div1.stage: Enter Dorothea, Lady Anderson and Nano.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: What news in Court, Nano let us know it?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: If so you please my Lord, I straight will show it:
The English king hath all the borders spoiled,
Hath taken Morton prisoner, and hath slain
Seven thousand Scottish Lords, not far from Twearde.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: A woeful murther, and a bloody deed.

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Thinking our liege hath sought by many means
For to appease his enemy by prayers,
Naught will prevail unless he can restore,
Fair Dorothea long supposed dead:
To this intent he hath proclaimed late,
That whosoever return the Queen to Court,
Shall have a thousand Marks for his reward.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: He loves her then I see although enforced,
That would bestow such gifts for to regain her:
Why sit you sad, good sir be not dismayed.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: I will lay my life this man would be a maid.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Fain would I show myself, and change my tire.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: Whereon divine you sir?

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Upon desire.
Madam mark but my skill, I will lay my life,
My master here, will prove a married wife.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Wilt thou bewray me Nano?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Madam no:
You are a man, and like a man you go.
But I that am in speculation seen,
Know you would change your state to be a Queen.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou art not dwarf to learn thy mistress: mind.
Fain would I with thyself disclose my kind,
But yet I blush.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: What blush you Madam than,
To be yourself, who are a feigned man?
Let me alone.

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: Deceitful beauty hast thou scorned me so?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Nay muse not maiden, for she tells you true.

sp.speaker: La. An.
sp.l: Beauty bred love, and love hath bred my shame.

sp.speaker: N.
sp.l: And women's faces work more wrongs than these:
Take comfort Madam to cure our disease.
And yet he loves a man as well as you,
Only this difference, she cannot fancy too.

sp.speaker: La. An.
sp.l: Blush, grieve, and die, in thine insatiate lust.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Nay live and joy that thou hast won a friend,
That loves thee as his life, by god desert.

sp.speaker: La. And.
sp.l: I joy my Lord more than my tongue can tell:
Although not as I desired, I love you well:
But modesty, that never blushed before,
Discover my false heart. I say no more.
Let me alone.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Good Nano stay a while.
Were I not sad, how kindly could I smile,
To see how fain I am to leave this weed:
And yet I faint to show myself indeed.
But danger hates delay, I will be bold,
Fair Lady I am not, suppose
A man, but even that Queen, more hapless I,
Whom Scottish King appointed hath to die:
I am the hapless Princess, for whose right,
These kings in bloody wars revenge despite.
I am that Dorothea whom they seek,
Yours bounden for your kindness and relief:
And since you are the means that save my life,
Yourself and I will to the Camp repair,
Whereas your husband shall enjoy reward,
And bring me to his highness once again.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Pardon most gracious Princess, if you please,
My rude discourse and homely entertain,
And if my words may savour any worth,
Vouchsafe my counsel in this weighty cause:
Since that our liege hath so unkindly dealt:
Give him no trust, return unto your sire,
There may you safely live in spite of him.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Ah Lady, so would worldly counsel work,
But constancy, obedience, and my love,
In that my husband is my Lord and chief,
These call me to compassion of his estate,
Dissuade me not, for virtue will not change,

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: What wondrous constancy is this I hear?
If English dames their husbands love so dear,
I fear me in the world they have no peer.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.l: Come Princes wend, and let us change your weed,
I long to see you now a Queen indeed.

div1.stage: Enter the King of Scots, the English Herald and Lords.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: He would have parley Lords, Herald say he shall,
And get thee gone: go leave me to myself:
Twixt love and fear, continual is the wars:
The one assures me of my Idaes love,
The other moves me for my murthered Queen.
Thus find I grief of that whereon I joy,
And doubt, in greatest hope, and death in weal,
Alas what hell may be compared with mine,
Since in extremes my comforts do consist?
War then will cease, when dead ones are revived.
Some then will yield, when I am dead for hope.
Who doth disturb me? Andrew?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: Aye my liege.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: What news?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: I think my mouth was made at first,
To tell these tragic tales my liefest Lord.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: What is Ateukin dead, tell me the worst?

sp.speaker: Andr.
sp.l: No but your Ida, shall I tell him all?
Is married late (ah shall I say to whom?)
My master sad: (for why he shames the Court)
Is fled away? ah most unhappy flight.
Only myself, ah who can love you more?
To show my duty (duty past belief)
Am come unto your grace (O gracious liege)
To let you know, O would it were not thus,
That love is vain, and maids soon lost and won.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: How have the partial heavens then dealt with me,
Boding my weal, for to abase my power?
Alas what thronging thoughts do me oppress?
Injurious love is partial in my right,
And flattering tongues by whom I was misled,
Have laid a snare to spoil my state and me.
Methinks I hear my Dorotheas ghost,
Howling revenge for my accursed hate,
The gifts of those my subjects that are slain,
Pursue me crying out, woe, woe, to lust,
The foe pursues me at my palace door:
He breaks my rest and spoils me in my Camp,
Ah flattering brood of Sycophants my foes,
First shall my dire revenge begin on you,
I will reward thee Andrew.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Nay sir if you be in your deeds of charity, remember me I ruled Master. Ateukins horse heels, when he rid to the meadows.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: And thou shalt have thy recompense for that.
Lords bear them to the prison, chain them fast,
Until we take some order for their deaths.

sp.speaker: And.
sp.l: If so your grace in such sort give rewards,
Let me have naught, I am content to want.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
Then I pray sir give me all, I am as ready for a reward as
an oyster for a fresh tide, spare not me sir.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Then hang them both as traitors to the King.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p:
The case is altered, sir, I will none of your gifts, what I take
a reward at your hands? Master, faith sir no: I am a man of a better conscience.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.p: Why dally you? go draw them hence away.

sp.speaker: Slip.
sp.p: Why alas sir, I will go away I thank you gentle friends. I pray you spare your pains, I will not trouble his honours mastership, I will run away.

div1.stage: Enter Adam, and Antiques, and carry away the Clown, he makes pots, and sports, and scorns.

sp.l: Why stay you? move me not, let search be made,
For vile Ateukin, whoso finds him out,
Shall have five hundredth marks for his reward.
Away with the Lords troupes about my tent,
Let all our soldiers stand in battle ray,
For lo the English to their parley come.

div1.stage:
March ouer bravely first the English hoste, the sword carried
before the King by Percy. The Scottish on the other side, with all their pomp bravely.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: What seeks the King of England in this land?

sp.speaker: K. of Eng.
sp.l: False traitorous Scot, I come for to revenge
My daughters death: I come to spoil thy wealth,
Since thou hast spoiled me of my marriage joy.
I come to heap thy land with Carcasses,
That this thy thrifty soil choked up with blood,
May thunder forth revenge upon thy head.
I come to quit thy loveless love with death,
In brief, no means of peace shall ever be found,
Except I have my daughter or thy head.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: My head proud King to abase thy pranking plains,
So striving fondly, mayst thou catch thy grave.
But if true judgment do direct thy course,
These lawful reasons should divide the war,
Faith not by my consent thy daughter died.

sp.speaker: K. of E.
sp.l: Thou liest false Scot, thy agents have confessed it.
These are but fond delays, thou canst not think
A means for to reconcile me for thy friend,
I have thy parasites confession penned:
What then canst thou allege in thy excuse?

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: I will repay the ransom for her blood.

sp.speaker: K. of E.
sp.l: What thinkst thou Caitiff, I will sell my child,
No if thou be a Prince and man at arms,
In single combat come and try thy right,
Else will I prove thee recreant to thy face.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: I took no combat false injurious King,
But since thou needless art inclined to war,
Do what thou darest we are in open field.
Arming thy battles I will fight with thee.

sp.speaker: K. of E.
sp.l: Agreed, now trumpets sound a dreadful charge
Fight for your Princess, brave English men:
Now for your lands your children and your wives,
My Scottish Peers, and lastly for your King.

div1.stage: Alarum sounded, both the battles offer to meet, and as the Kings are joining battle, Enter sir Cutber to his Lady Cutbert, with the Queen Dorothea richly attired.

sp.speaker: S. Cut.
sp.l: Stay Princes wage not war, a privy grudge
Twixt such as you (most high in Majesty)
Afflicts both nocent and the innocent,
How many swords dear Princes see I drawn?
The friend against his friend, a deadly friend:
A desperate division in those lands,
Which if they join in one, command the world.
O stay with reason mitigate your rage,
And let an old man humbled on his knees,
Entreat a boon good Princes of you both.

sp.speaker: K. of En.
sp.l: I condescend, for why thy reverend years
Import some news of truth and consequence,
I am content, for Anderson I know.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Thou art my subject and dost mean me good.

sp.speaker: S. Cut. And.
sp.l: But by your gracious favours grant me this,
To swear upon your sword to do me right.

sp.speaker: K. of Eng.
sp.l: See by my sword, and by a Princes faith,
In every lawful sort I am thine own.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: And by my Sceptre and the Scottish Crown,
I am resolved to grant thee thy request.

sp.speaker: Cuth.
sp.l: I see you trust me Princes who repose,
The weight of such a war upon my will.
Now mark my suit, a tender lions whelp,
This other day came straggling in the woods,
Attended by a young and tender hind,
In courage haughty, yet attired like a lamb,
The Prince of beasts had left this young in keep,
To foster up as lovemate and compeer,
Unto the lions mate a neighbour friend,
This stately guide seduced by the fox,
Sent forth an eager Wolf bred up in France,
That gripped the tender whelp, and wounded it.
By chance as I was hunting in the woods,
I heard the moan the hind made for the whelp,
I took them both, and brought them to my house,
With chary care I have recured the one,
And since I know the lions are at strife,
About the loss and damage of the young,
I bring her home, make claim to her who list.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: I am the whelp, bred by this lion up,
This royal English king my happy sire,
Poor Nano is the hind that tended me:
My father Scottish king, gave me to thee:
A hapless wife, thou quite misled by youth,
Hast sought sinister loves and foreign joys,
The fox Ateukin, cursed Parasite,
Incensed your grace to send the wolf abroad,
The French born Iaques, for to end my days,
He traitorous man, pursued me in the woods,
And left me wounded, where this noble knight,
Both rescued me and mine, and saved my life.
Now keep thy promise, Dorothea lives:
Give Anderson his due and just reward:
And since you kings, your wars began by me,
Since I am safe, return surcease your fight.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Durst I presume to look upon those eyes,
Which I have tired with a world of woes,
Or did I think submission were enough,
Or sighs might make an entrance to my soul:
You heavens, you know how willing I would weep:
You heavens can tell, how glad I would submit:
You heavens can say, how firmly I would sigh.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Shame me not Prince, companion in thy bed,
Youth hath misled: tut but a little fault,
It is kingly to amend what is amiss:
Might I with twice as many pains as these,
Unite our hearts, then should my wedded Lord,
See how incessant labours I would take.
My gracious father govern your affects,
Give me that hand, that oft hath blessed this head,
And clasp thine arms, that have embraced this,
About the shoulders of my wedded spouse:
Ah mighty Prince, this king and I am one,
Spoil thou his subjects, thou despoilest me:
Touch thou his breast, thou dost attaint this heart,
O be my father then in loving him.

sp.speaker: K. of Eng.
sp.l: Thou provident kind mother of increase,
Thou must prevail, ah nature thou must rule:
Hold daughter, join my hand and his in one,
I will embrace him for to favour thee,
I call him friend, and take him for my son.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ah royal husband, see what God hath wrought,
Thy foe is now thy friend: good men at arms,
Do you the like, these nations if they join,
What Monarch with his liegemen in this world,
Dare but encounter you in open field?

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: All wisdom joined with godly piety,
Thou English king, pardon my former youth,
And pardon courteous Queen my great misdeed:
And for assurance of mine after life,
I take religious vows before my God,
To honour thee for favour, her for wife.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: But yet my boons good Princes are not past,
First English king I humbly do request,
That by your means our Princess may unite,
Her love unto mine alder truest love,
Now you will love, maintain and help them both.

sp.speaker: K. of Eng.
sp.l: Good Anderson, I grant thee thy request.

sp.speaker: L. And.
sp.l: But you my Prince must yield me mickle more:
You know your Nobles are your chiefest stays,
And long time have been banished from your Court,
Embrace and reconcile them to yourself.
They are your hands, whereby you ought to work.
As for Ateukin, and his lewd compeers,
That soothed you in your sins and youthly pomp,
Exile, torment, and punish such as they,
For greater vipers never may be found
Within a state, than such aspiring heads,
That reck not how they clime, so that they clime.

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Good Knight I grant thy suit, first I submit
And humble crave a pardon of your grace:
Next courteous Queen, I pray thee by thy loves,
Forgive mine errors past, and pardon me.
My Lords and Princes, if I have misdone,
(As I have wronged indeed both you and yours)
Hereafter trust me, you are dear to me:
As for Anteukin, whoso finds the man,
Let him have Martial law, and straight be hanged,
As (all his vain arbiters now are divided)
And Anderson our Treasurer shall pay,
Three thousand Marks, for friendly recompense.

sp.speaker: L. Andr.
sp.l: But Princes whilst you friend it thus in one,
Methinks of friendship, Nano shall have none.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: What would my Dwarf, that I will not bestow?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: My boon fair Queen is this, that you would go,
Although my body is but small and neat,
My stomach after toil requireth meat,
An easy suit, dread Princes will you wend?

sp.speaker: K. of S.
sp.l: Art thou a Pygmy born my pretty friend?

sp.speaker: Nano.
sp.l: Not so great King, but nature when she framed me,
Was scant of earth, and Nano therefore named me:
And when she saw my body was so small,
She gave me wit to make it big withal.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Till time when,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Eat then.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: My friend it stands with wit,
To take repast when stomach serveth it.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thy policy my Nano shall prevail:
Come royal father, enter we my tent:
And soldiers feast it, frolic it like friends,
My Princes bid this kind and courteous train,
Partake some favours of our late accord.
Thus wars have end, and after dreadful hate,
Men learn at last to know their good estate.
